{{AI-generated|date=May 2024}}
'''Digital ecology''' is a science about the interdependence of digital systems and the [[natural environment]].<ref>{{Cite book |title="Digital Ecology : The Complete Guide". June 9, 2022.}}</ref> This field of study looks at the methods in which digital technologies are changing the way how people interact with the environment, as well as how these technologies affects the environment itself. It is a branch of [[ecology]] that promotes green practices to fight digital pollution.<ref>{{Cite book |title="Digital ecology". Philonomist. November 10, 2021.}}</ref> Currently the total [[Electronic waste|carbon footprint]] of the internet, our electronic devices, and supporting elements accounts for about 3.7% of global greenhouse gas emissions (including about 1.4 per cent of overall global carbon dioxide emissions).<ref>{{Citation |last1=Mager |first1=David |title=Carbon—Quantifying and Reducing Your Carbon Footprint |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5848/bk.978-1-60509-468-7_10 |work=Street Smart Sustainability: The Entrepreneur's Guide to Profitably Greening Your Organization's DNA |pages=129–136 |access-date=2023-03-04 |publisher=Berrett-Koehler Publishers, Inc. |last2=Sibilia |first2=Joe|date=2010 |doi=10.5848/bk.978-1-60509-468-7_10 |isbn=978-1-60509-468-7 |url-access=subscription }}</ref>
Digital Ecology can also be used to denote the use of technology in the study of ecological systems and processing, examining how technological developments aid in the collection, analysis and management of ecological data.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2025-03-04|language=en|title=What is Digital Ecology?|url=https://sites.google.com/view/digitalecology/home/|website=What is Digital Ecology?}}</ref> Important fields in this aspect of Digital Ecology include the development of drone technology for wildlife monitoring.
Digital ecology is a complex and multifaceted field that requires a holistic approach to understanding the relationship between digital technologies and the natural world. With the increasing reliance on digital technologies, it is important to consider the environmental consequences of these technologies and work towards more sustainable solutions.
== Negative impact on the environment == One of the main areas of focus in digital ecology is the impact of [[electronic waste]], or e-waste. As more and more devices become obsolete and are replaced with newer models, the amount of e-waste being produced is increasing at an alarming rate. This e-waste often ends up in landfills, where it can leach harmful chemicals into the soil and water supply.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|author=Andreas. langer@tcodevelopment.com|language=en-US|title=E-waste — a toxic waste stream where valuable finite resources are lost|url=https://tcocertified.com/e-waste/|website=TCO Certified}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref>
Another aspect of digital ecology is the energy consumption of digital technologies and the digital pollution in causes. The production and use of digital devices requires significant amounts of energy, and as the demand for these devices increases, so does the amount of energy required to meet this demand.. The total [[Electronic waste|carbon footprint]] of the internet, our electronic devices, and supporting elements add up to about 3.7% of global greenhouse gas emissions. It is as much as for the airline industry and the number keeps on rising.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|title=ec0lint|url=https://www.ec0lint.com/blog/introduction-to-digital-ecology|website=www.ec0lint.com}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> This increase in energy consumption has a negative impact on the environment, as it contributes to [[climate change]] and [[air pollution]]. Research has shown, that if the internet was a country, it would be the seventh largest polluter in the world, by some estimates.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|language=en|title=Cognizant BrandVoice: How To Be Both Digital And 'Green' At The Same Time|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/cognizant/2021/09/21/how-to-be-both-digital-and-green-at-the-same-time/|website=Forbes}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --> {{ugc|date= September 2024}}</ref>
=== Digital pollution === Digital pollution is a crucial aspect of digital ecology. It is the main problem against which digital ecology is fighting. Digital pollution refers to the negative impact of digital technology and [[electronic waste]] on the environment and human health. This can include emissions from electronic devices, toxic chemicals in electronic waste, and the proliferation of [[e-waste]] in landfills.
Technology users contribute to digital pollution on a daily basis, which include:
* '''[[Cloud storage|Data clouds]] and servers''' - keeping many data on clouds and servers and transferring them contribute to air pollution through the energy used to power and cool these data centers and sending the data. The energy consumption of data centers results in emissions of greenhouse gases, such as harmful carbon dioxide.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|website=Stanford Magazine|date=2017-06-27|language=en|title=Carbon and the Cloud|url=https://medium.com/stanford-magazine/carbon-and-the-cloud-d6f481b79dfe| via= Medium}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> The energy is generated by power plants, which often burn fossil fuels such as [[coal]], [[oil]], and [[natural gas]], releasing harmful pollutants into the air. In addition, the [[air conditioning]] systems used to cool the servers also consume a significant amount of energy and release heat into the environment. This is primarily influenced by large databases, but people's day-to-day activities are also not insignificant. An example of this would be '''storing and accessing emails'''.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|language=en|title=Spam Statistics 2022 |type= blog |url=https://99firms.com/blog/spam-statistics|website=99firms.com}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> An average year of emailing emits about 136 kilograms of {{CO2}}. One inbox consumes enough energy to run a hot shower for about 4 minutes, which is equal to illuminating 40 lightbulbs for an hour and equal to pollution by driving a car 212 metres.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-21|language=en|title=Thanks in Advance|url=https://thanks-in-advance.com/|website=Thanks in Advance}} {{verify source|date=September 2024}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> Addictionally, [[data center]]s consume large amounts of energy to power and cool the servers that store and process spam email data, resulting in emissions of greenhouse gases and other pollutants.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|language=en|title=A guide to your digital carbon footprint – and how to lower it|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2021/12/digital-carbon-footprint-how-to-lower-electronics/|website=World Economic Forum|date=9 December 2021 }}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> * '''Production of electronic devices''' - has a detrimental effect on the environment for several reasons: increasing the [[demand]] for [[raw material]]s, rare earth minerals, energy, water usage, and other resources, and contribute to [[environmental degradation]] through the associated pollution and waste.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|date=2022-03-24|language=en|title=Are Electronics Bad for the Environment?|url=https://thesustainabilitycooperative.net/2022/03/24/are-electronics-bad-for-the-environment/|website=The Sustainability Co-Op}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> Manufacturing is the most polluting phase. It accounts for up to 80% of a device's carbon footprint during its lifetime. Buying new equipment every six years rather than every four reduces [[carbon dioxide]] production by 190 kg. * '''Energy-inefficient electronics -''' they consume more [[electricity]], which in turn requires more energy to be generated, often from power plants that burn [[fossil fuel]]s. Additionally, inefficient electronics also generate more heat, which requires more energy for cooling, further increasing the total energy consumption and associated emissions. When these electronic devices reach the end of their lifespan and are disposed of, they can also become electronic waste, which can release toxic chemicals into the [[Natural environment|environment]].<ref>{{cite conference <!-- Citation bot no -->|access-date=2023-02-03|author1=Nihal Sinnadurai | author2= Harry K. Charles|title=IEEE 32nd International Spring Seminar on Electronics Technology |date=May 2009|doi=10.1109/ISSE.2009.5206941|pages=1–10|chapter=Electronics and its impact on energy and the environment|chapter-url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5206941|isbn=978-1-4244-4260-7 |s2cid=25323873 }}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> * '''Unnecessary charging of electronic devices -''' can contribute to air pollution through the increased energy consumption. Unnecessary charging of devices, such as [[smartphone]]s or laptops, increases the overall energy demand and contributes to emissions from power plants.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|date=2015-08-10|language=en|title=Learn about Energy and its Impact on the Environment|url=https://www.epa.gov/energy/learn-about-energy-and-its-impact-environment|website= US Environmental Protection Agency}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> Charging smartphones generates more [[carbon dioxide]] than charging laptops. * '''Electronic waste''' - electronic devices eventually reach the end of their lifespan and become waste. The improper disposal of electronic waste release toxic chemicals into the environment, [[Soil contamination|contaminating soil]] and water, and harming wildlife.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|language=en|title=E-waste: An Emerging Health Risk|url=https://www.niehs.nih.gov/research/programs/geh/geh_newsletter/2014/2/spotlight/ewaste_an_emerging_health_risk_.cfm|website=Global Environmental Health Newsletter}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref>
== Positive impact on the environment == Despite the environmental impact of electronic devices and data centers, digital technologies positively impact the environment in a variety of ways:<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|date=2022-01-17|language=en-US|title=Positive Effect Of Information Technology On Environment|url=https://techjournal.org/effect-of-information-technology-on-environment/}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref>
* '''[[Efficient energy use|Energy efficiency]]''': Digital technologies can help increase energy efficiency through the use of smart energy systems, such as smart grid systems and energy-efficient devices.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|title=How digitalisation is modernising energy efficiency|url=https://www.europeanenergyinnovation.eu/Articles/Autumn-2019/How-digitalisation-is-modernising-energy-efficiency|website=www.europeanenergyinnovation.eu}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> * '''Reduced waste''': The use of digital technologies can reduce waste by reducing the need for paper and other physical materials.<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2023-02-03|language=en|title=Digital technologies will deliver more efficient waste management in Europe — European Environment Agency|url=https://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/waste/waste-management/digital-technologies-will-deliver-more|website=www.eea.europa.eu}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref> * '''Enhanced education''': Digital technologies can enhance education by providing access to information and resources, promoting sustainable practices and environmental awareness.<ref>{{cite journal|access-date=2023-02-03|author=Abid Haleem, Mohd Javaid, Mohd Asim Qadri, Rajiv Suman|date=2022-01-01|doi=10.1016/j.susoc.2022.05.004|issn=2666-4127|journal=Sustainable Operations and Computers|language=en|pages=275–285|title=Understanding the role of digital technologies in education: A review|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2666412722000137|volume=3|s2cid=249055862 |doi-access=free|bibcode=2022soc..book..275H }}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref>

{{Short description|3D Apple Maps feature}} {{Other uses|Flyover (disambiguation){{!}}Flyover}} '''Flyover''' is a feature on [[Apple Maps]] that allows users to view certain areas in a [[3D scanning|3D setting]]. Flyover also allows users to take "tours" of these locations through the City Tours feature, showcasing various landmarks in the area. Imagery is provided through the use of planes, which [[Aerial photography|collect]] fine data on buildings. {{Infobox software | name = Flyover | logo = | logo size = | screenshot = File:Apple Flyover (Toronto).png | screenshot size = | caption = Flyover showing [[Toronto]] on the [[iPad Pro]] | released = {{Start date and age|2012|9|19}} | ver layout = simple | platform = [[iOS]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/ios/feature-availability/|title=iOS and iPadOS 17 Feature Availability|publisher=Apple Support|accessdate=20 December 2023}}
[[iPadOS]]
[[macOS]]{{Cite web|last=Kazmucha|first=Allyson|url=https://www.imore.com/how-use-flyover-feature-apple-maps-mac|title=How to use the Flyover feature in Apple Maps for Mac|date=13 February 2014 |publisher=iMore|accessdate=21 December 2023}} | language = Multiple languages | website = }} Initially founded in 2012, along with Apple Maps itself, Flyover now covers over 300 cities, landmarks, and [[national parks|parks]] across five of the six inhabited continents through a series of several expansions, notably in 2014, 2015 and 2019. Despite earlier issues, Flyover has been praised for its detail and uniqueness.{{Cite web|last=Bell|first=Karissa|url=https://mashable.com/article/apple-maps-flyover|title=Watch out Google Earth, Apple Maps has a hidden VR-like 'flyover' mode|date=28 June 2017 |publisher=Mashable|accessdate=18 November 2023}} == History == ===2012–2015=== Flyover was announced along with Apple Maps at the [[WWDC 2012]], and was also released alongside Maps in September 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://localsplash.com/apple-announces-new-maps-app-at-wwdc-2012?noRedirect=true|title=Apple Announces New Maps App at WWDC 2012|date=11 June 2012 |publisher=Local Splash|accessdate=12 September 2023}} The 10 initial cities that first received Flyover were [[Chicago]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Las Vegas]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Miami]], [[Montreal]], [[Sacramento]], [[San Francisco]], [[Seattle]] and [[Sydney]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.cultofmac.com/173690/here-all-all-the-cities-you-can-flyover-in-ios-6-maps-gallery/|title=Here All All The Cities You Can Flyover In iOS 6 Maps|date=14 June 2012 |publisher=Cult of Mac|accessdate=13 October 2023}} More cities would receive Flyover in later years, with [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] often adding multiple cities to Flyover at a time.{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2019/01/08/apple-maps-flyover-updated-locations/|title=New Flyover and indoor maps locations now available in Apple Maps|publisher=9to5Mac|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.actualidadiphone.com/en/apple-adds-11-more-cities-to-flyover-on-its-maps/|title=Apple adds 11 more cities to Flyover on its maps|date=28 January 2015 |publisher=Actualidad iPhone|accessdate=12 September 2023}} In addition to this initial release, Apple added the feature to other cities later in the year, including [[Toronto]] in Canada.{{Cite web|url=https://urbantoronto.ca/news/2012/09/toronto-arrives-3d-apples-ios6.6393|title=Toronto Arrives in 3D in Apple's iOS6|publisher=Urban Toronto|accessdate=14 September 2023}} In 2013, Flyover was added to Paris, as well as smaller cities such as [[Indianapolis]] and [[Baltimore]], totalling 16 cities in the United States, Germany, Canada, France and the UK.{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2014/01/15/apple-expands-3d-flyover-coverage-in-maps-to-cape-town-and-helsinki/|title=Apple expands 3D Flyover coverage in Maps to Cape Town and Helsinki|publisher=9to5Mac|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.loopinsight.com/2013/03/12/apples-maps-being-updated-often-and-significantly/|title=Apple's Maps being updated often and significantly|publisher=The Loop|accessdate=12 September 2023}} In addition, Flyover was also added to London, [[Barcelona]], [[Cologne]],{{Cite web|url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/13/03/13/apple-continues-rollout-of-flyover-support-3d-buildings-turn-by-turn-navigation-in-multiple-cities|title=Apple adds iOS Maps Flyover support, 3D buildings, turn-by-turn navigation in multiple cities|date=13 March 2013 |publisher=Apple Insider|accessdate=19 October 2023}} Rome, and [[Madrid]],{{Cite web|url=https://gadgethelpline.com/apple-adds-flyover-3d-maps-15-cities-apple-maps/|title=Apple adds Flyover and 3D Maps to 15 new cities in Apple Maps|date=13 March 2013 |publisher=Gadget Helpline|accessdate=14 September 2023}} as well as the city of Vancouver, in Canada the same year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cultofmac.com/219490/apple-continues-to-bring-flyover-3d-buildings-to-more-cities-in-maps/|title=Apple Continues To Bring Flyover & 3D Buildings To More Cities In Maps|date=13 March 2013 |publisher=Cult of Mac|accessdate=7 October 2023}} Flyover was added to several cities and national parks in New Zealand, France, the United States, South Africa, Sweden and Japan, including [[Cape Town]] and two [[Arizona]] National Parks in 2014,{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2014/12/05/apple-flyover-movie-showtimes/|title=Apple Adds New Flyover Locations to Maps, Siri Movie Showtimes in More Countries|date=5 December 2014 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=12 September 2023}} with [[Marseille]], the second-largest city in France, receiving Flyover coverage later in the year as well. The capital of Japan, [[Tokyo]], also received Flyover that year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2014/06/27/toyko-zion-national-park-flyover/|title=Tokyo, Zion National Park Added to Apple Maps Flyover Feature|date=27 June 2014 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=20 October 2023}} along with [[Wellington]], New Zealand and [[Yosemite National Park]].{{Cite web|last=Clover|first=Juli|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2014/08/19/yosemite-wellington-added-to-flyover/|title=Yosemite National Park and Wellington, New Zealand Added to Apple Maps Flyover Feature|date=19 August 2014 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=1 November 2023}} In addition, the City Tours feature, which allows users to tour locations supported by the Flyover feature, was also added around this time.{{Cite web|last=Smith|first=Chris|url=https://news.yahoo.com/one-way-apple-maps-getting-better-google-maps-164025134.html|title=Here's one way Apple Maps is getting better than Google Maps|date=20 June 2014 |publisher=Yahoo News|accessdate=12 November 2023}} South Africa, the only African nation to have Flyover, also first saw the feature with Cape Town in 2014, with [[Durban]] and [[Johannesburg]] receiving the feature in later years.{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2016/02/03/apple-20-new-flyover-locations/|title=Apple Adds 20 New Flyover Locations Around the World, New Maps Info in Taiwan and Finland|date=3 February 2016 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=12 September 2023}} Flyover was added to over 20 cities and locations in 2015 in various cities mostly across the US and Western Europe, including [[Canberra]] and [[Venice]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2015/04/30/apple-adds-20-flyover-locations-maps/|title=Apple Adds 20 New Flyover Locations to Maps|date=30 April 2015 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2015/02/24/apple-flyover-cities/|title=Apple adding 9 new 3D Flyover locations to Maps|publisher=9to5Mac|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|last=England|first=Lucy|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/new-apple-maps-flyover-locations-2015-9|title=New Apple Maps Flyover Locations|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=23 March 2024}} Flyover was also added to [[Budapest]], in [[Hungary]]{{Cite web|url=https://welovebudapest.com/en/article/2015/1/2/tour-budapest-in-3d-with-apple-maps-flyover-tour|title=Tour Budapest in 3D with Apple Maps – Flyover Tour|date=2 January 2015 |publisher=We Love Budapest|accessdate=14 September 2023}} and [[Prague]] and [[Brno]] in the [[Czech Republic]] later in the year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.letemsvetemapplem.eu/2023/09/24/macos-hry-ktere-nyni-stahnete-zcela-zdarma/#al1|title=Praha začala podporovat FlyOver v Apple Maps!|date=24 September 2023 |accessdate=24 September 2023}} In Italy, the cities of [[Florence]] and [[Genoa]] and [[Neuschwanstein Castle]] in Germany received Flyover that year as well.{{Cite web|last=Hunt|first=Gordon|url=https://www.siliconrepublic.com/life/apples-maps-3d-flyover-expand-to-cities-in-france-italy-japan-and-more|title=Apple's 3D Flyover maps expand to cities in Italy, Japan and beyond|date=29 September 2015 |publisher=Silicon Republic|accessdate=28 October 2023}}{{Cite web|last=McCormick|first=Rich|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/29/9413583/apple-maps-3d-flyover-view-new-cities|title=Apple Maps adds its 3D flyover view to new cities, towns, and castles|date=29 September 2015 |publisher=The Verge|accessdate=23 March 2024}} [[Guadalajara]], the largest city in [[Mexico]] to have the feature, also received Flyover in 2015.{{Cite web|last=Kahn|first=Jordan|url=https://9to5mac.com/2015/02/24/apple-flyover-cities/|title=Apple adding 9 new 3D Flyover locations to Maps|publisher=9to5Mac|accessdate=31 October 2023}} Japan also saw more cities with Flyover, with [[Nagoya]], [[Osaka]] and [[Hiroshima]] receiving the feature in 2015 as well,{{Cite web|url=https://forums.macrumors.com/threads/apple-adds-new-flyover-locations-expands-nearby-feature-to-australia-canada-france-and-germany.1932338/|title=Apple Adds New Flyover Locations, Expands 'Nearby' Feature to Australia, Canada, France and Germany|date=26 October 2015 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=4 November 2023}} and [[Mannheim]] and [[Stuttgart]] in Germany also received the feature that year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/new-apple-maps-flyover-locations-2015-9?amp=|title=Here are all the amazing new locations you can fly over with Apple Maps|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=20 October 2023}} An additional 7 cities received Flyover in June of the same year, those being the cities of [[Karlsruhe]] and [[Kiel]] in Germany, [[Braga]] in Portugal, [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] in Puerto Rico, [[Cadiz]] and [[Jerez de la Frontera]] in Spain, and [[Kingston-upon-Hull|Hull]] in the United Kingdom.{{Cite web|last=Lee|first=Cody|url=https://www.idownloadblog.com/2015/06/24/apple-maps-7-new-flyover-spots/|title=Apple adds 7 new Flyover locations to Maps|date=24 June 2015 |publisher=iDownloadBlog|accessdate=26 October 2023}}{{Cite web|url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/15/06/24/apple-adds-maps-flyover-support-for-7-cities-in-spain-germany-uk-and-puerto-rico|title=Apple adds Maps Flyover support for 7 cities in Spain, Germany, UK and Puerto Rico|date=24 June 2015 |publisher=Apple Insider|accessdate=23 March 2024}} ===2016–present=== 2016 saw Apple add Flyover to around 20 additional cities, including cities such as [[Adelaide]] in Australia and the [[Virgin Islands]], with the majority of the new cities being smaller ones, as only two of the cities that received Flyover that year had over a million people.{{Cite web|last=Lovejoy|first=Ben|url=https://9to5mac.com/2016/02/04/apple-maps-flyover-locations/|title=Apple Maps adds 5 new U.S. Flyover locations, 15 more international ones|publisher=9to5Mac|accessdate=9 November 2023}} 2019 saw one of Apple's biggest Flyover expansions, with the feature being added to over 30 cities in France, Japan, the United States, and others, as well as the entirety of the nation of [[Monaco]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2019/01/08/apple-maps-flyover-mall-locations/|title=Apple Maps Gains New Indoor Mall Maps and Flyover Locations|date=8 January 2019 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2019/01/08/apple-maps-flyover-updated-locations/|title=New Flyover and indoor maps locations now available in Apple Maps|publisher=9to5mac|accessdate=6 November 2023}} This would remain the largest amount of new cities added in a single year until 2024, five years later. After 2019 and during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], relatively little progress was made with the feature, largely in favor of other newer features. However, Apple added some new Flyovers during and since then, expanding to [[Amsterdam]] in 2020{{Cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2020/09/03/apple-maps-transit-3d-view-portugal-netherlands/|title=Apple Maps Expands Public Transit Information and 3D View in Portugal and the Netherlands|date=3 September 2020 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|last=Neely|first=Amber|url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/20/09/03/apple-maps-now-has-3d-images-in-amsterdam-transit-information-in-portugal|title=Apple Maps now has 3D images in Amsterdam, transit information in Portugal|date=3 September 2020 |publisher=Apple Insider|accessdate=6 November 2023}} and [[Vienna]] in 2023.{{Cite web|url=https://www.oe24.at/oesterreich/chronik/wien-bald-in-3d-apple-maps-vermisst-hauptstadt/520804076|title=Wien bald in 3D: Apple Maps vermisst Hauptstadt (in German)|date=June 2022 |publisher=oe24|accessdate=12 September 2023}} Another major rollout of Flyover occurred in 2024, with dozens of cities across North America, Australia, and Europe receiving the feature, including [[Washington D.C.]],{{cite web|url=https://www.unilad.com/technology/news/apple-maps-google-maps-comparison-464100-20240821|last=Roberts|first=Kit|title=People notice major difference in Google Maps and Apple Maps but are divided on which is better|publisher=Unilad|accessdate=6 May 2025}} [[Kansas City]],{{cite web|last=Popa|first=Bogdan|url=https://www.autoevolution.com/news/apple-maps-flyover-quietly-launches-in-new-regions-233196.html|title=Apple Maps Flyover Quietly Launches in New Regions|date=30 April 2024 |publisher=autoevolution|accessdate=3 June 2024}} and [[Brisbane]].{{Cite web|last=Brookes|first=Tim|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tech/why-switched-google-maps-apple-130014614.html|title=Why I switched from Google Maps to Apple Maps|publisher=Yahoo Tech|accessdate=25 November 2024}} These updates continued into 2025, with [[Lisbon]], [[Frankfurt]], and several other cities receiving Flyover.{{Cite web|url=https://www.heise.de/en/news/3D-flyover-Apple-Maps-adds-new-flyover-images-in-Germany-10249550.html|title=3D flyover: Apple Maps adds new flyover images in Germany|publisher=Heise|accessdate=16 February 2025}} == Use == Apple collects the 3D data used for Flyover by using small military-grade{{Cite web|last=Orange|first=Richard|url=https://www.thelocal.no/20130812/oslo-bans-apples-mapping-drones|title=Oslo bans Apple's mapping drones|publisher=The Local|accessdate=12 November 2023}} [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]]-like planes, which fly up close to buildings to create a more detailed map. As of 2013, [[C3 Technologies]], a Swedish company which was acquired by Apple in 2011, has collected the data used for Flyover.{{Cite web|url=https://www.applegazette.com/apple-inc/how-apple-creates-3d-flyover-maps/|title=How Apple Creates 3D Flyover Maps|publisher=Apple Gazette|accessdate=12 September 2023}} With Flyover, certain locations – mostly big cities, landmarks and some national parks – can be seen from a birds-eye perspective. The three-dimensional views are photo-realistic, and users can change the vantage point on the map.{{Cite web |title=Apple: Maps |url=https://www.apple.com/ios/maps/ |access-date=December 30, 2015}} Flyover imagery has been viewed as similar to that of [[virtual reality]], and could possibly be a precursor to a VR feature on Maps.{{Cite web|last=Elliott|first=Matt|url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/mobile/take-awesome-vr-tours-with-apple-maps-flyover-feature/|title=Take awesome VR tours with Apple Map's Flyover feature|publisher=CNET|accessdate=18 November 2023}} === City Tours === Flyover City Tours were released around 2014, but was inaccessible for a time until the feature was debugged by an Apple Maps developer, making it public. City Tours is a feature that allows users to view various landmarks in a given city via a "flying" animation, a feature only available to cities that already contain Flyover 3D maps.{{Cite web|url=https://appletoolbox.com/what-is-the-flyover-feature-in-apple-maps/|title=What Is the Flyover Feature in Apple Maps?|date=29 March 2023 |publisher=AppleToolBox|accessdate=12 September 2023}} City Tours was added as a feature to Apple Maps on [[iOS 8]] on September 17, 2014, and in [[OS X Yosemite]] on October 16, 2014.{{Cite web|last=Slivka|first=Eric|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2014/09/07/flyover-city-tours/|title=Apple Filling Out Flyover City Tours Ahead of iOS 8 and OS X Yosemite Launches|date=7 September 2014 |publisher=MacRumors|accessdate=17 November 2023}} Most, but not all cities with Flyover allow tours of a given city, where the above virtual tour of various landmarks in the area will be shown.{{Cite web|url=https://support.apple.com/guide/iphone/take-flyover-tours-iph81a3f978/ios|title=Take Flyover tours in Maps on iPhone|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=12 September 2023}} == Coverage == [[File:Flyover Availability-2.png|thumb|Countries (in green) with at least one location with Flyover]] Flyovers are available in over 350{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/9/30/20888734/apple-maps-update-northeast-transit-google-maps|title=Apple Maps is looking better than ever, but it still has a long way to go|date=30 September 2019 |publisher=The Verge|accessdate=6 November 2023}} cities, metropolitan areas, national parks and landmarks across 29 countries in North America, Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia, as of 2024.{{Cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/ios/feature-availability/#maps-flyover|title=iOS and iPadOS 17 Feature Availability|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{efn|Note that 3D coverage is generally not limited to the cities targeted for Flyover (see below) and often covers surrounding towns and communities in the area. For example, [[Cologne]] and [[Düsseldorf]] both have Flyover, and in addition to their coverage, all areas between the two cities, such as [[Solingen]] and [[Leverkusen]], also have Flyover.}} {| class=wikitable |+ Locations with Flyovers |- ! Controversy == ===Errors=== Similar to Maps itself, Flyover saw many visual issues upon release, a notable one containing a massive glitch on the [[Brooklyn Bridge|Brooklyn]] and [[Anzac Bridge|Anzac]] bridges in New York and Sydney, showing "plunges" on both structures.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/petercohan/2012/09/27/apple-maps-six-most-epic-fails/|title=Apple Maps' Six Most Epic Fails|work=Forbes|accessdate=19 October 2023}} This was part of a larger series of technical issues with Apple Maps, most of which have since been fixed. ===Security concerns=== In 2013, the Norwegian government denied a request by Apple to add Flyover to [[Oslo]], the Norwegian capital, citing security concerns arising from the amount of detail given to buildings, information which could potentially be used to facilitate and carry out terrorist attacks.{{Cite news|last=Dewey|first=Caitlin|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/08/13/why-norway-is-blocking-apple-maps-from-taking-3d-images-of-oslo/|title=Why Norway is blocking Apple Maps from taking 3D images of Oslo|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=12 September 2023}}{{Cite web|last=Gates|first=Sara|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/norway-blocks-apple-3d-mapping-flyover-oslo_n_3743600|title= Norway Blocks Apple From 3D Mapping Oslo For Maps App Flyover View|date= 12 August 2013|publisher=Huff Post|accessdate=12 September 2023}} The decision was met with criticism from [[Fabian Stang]], then mayor of Oslo, who called for the Norwegian government to allow Apple to add the feature, citing the possibility of increased tourism from the addition.{{Cite web|last=Grothaus|first=Michael|url=https://news.yahoo.com/2013-08-12-norwegian-government-bans-apple-from-capturing-3d-flyover-maps-d.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAADrwQMxdHIFhyQwN23rC3K7A8fxr8PAroGgc8HN5FigWfY9dq1Hj9Nb4hAw5azYh-7JZKpPiRtBjTOus3Lcep5gRs-IkzLvieqnCL5ZAIER9U7L_-3erJ7kxr4oDyZygymtMBrxP6VX1x7RecRjoy-Sq_ZqHse6U1x7Nv7Y7qXg0|title=Norwegian government bans Apple from capturing 3D Flyover Maps data in Oslo|date=12 August 2013 |publisher=Yahoo News|accessdate=23 December 2023}} A spokesperson for the [[National Security Authority (Norway)|National Security Authority]] of Norway stated that obtaining the needed imagery from a "Norwegian supplier" or from the [[Norwegian Mapping Authority]] could potentially assist Apple in adding the feature.{{Cite news|last=Kleinman|first=Zoe|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-23675327|title=Apple aerial map photos blocked over Oslo in Norway|work=BBC News |date=12 August 2013 |accessdate=23 December 2023}} The US embassy in Norway also stated its support for Apple in adding the feature.{{Cite web|url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/13/08/12/apples-request-to-conduct-3d-mapping-of-oslo-denied-by-norwegian-government|title=Apple's request to conduct 3D mapping of Oslo denied by Norwegian government|date=12 August 2013 |publisher=Apple Insider|accessdate=25 March 2024}} Flyover was eventually added to Oslo in late 2023, 11 years after the initial incident. Similar security concerns may have also prevented Apple from adding Flyover to other potentially sensitive areas, including [[Washington D.C.]] (which eventually got the feature in May 2024), among others. == See also == *[[3D modeling]] *[[Google Earth]] *[[Pre-installed iOS apps]] == Notes == {{notelist}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://www.apple.com/ios/feature-availability/#maps-flyover Locations with Flyover Tours] (Apple Inc.) {{Apple}} [[Category:Apple Inc. software]] [[Category:Technology]] [[Category:Maps]]

'''Moral outsourcing''' refers to placing responsibility for ethical decision-making on to external entities, often [[Algorithm|algorithms]]. The term is often used in discussions of [[computer science]] and [[Fairness (machine learning)|algorithmic fairness]],<ref name=":0">{{Citation |last=Chowdhury |first=Rumman |title=Moral Outsourcing: Humanity in the age of AI |date=2018-06-08 |url=https://www.ted.com/talks/rumman_chowdhury_moral_outsourcing_humanity_in_the_age_of_ai |access-date=2023-11-28}}</ref> but it can apply to any situation in which one appeals to outside agents in order to absolve themselves of responsibility for their actions. In this context, moral outsourcing specifically refers to the tendency of society to blame technology, rather than its creators or users, for any harm it may cause.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |date=2023-05-29 |title='I do not think ethical surveillance can exist': Rumman Chowdhury on accountability in AI |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/may/29/rumman-chowdhury-interview-artificial-intelligence-accountability |access-date=2023-10-14 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
== Definition == The term "moral outsourcing" was first coined by Dr. [[Rumman Chowdhury]], a data scientist concerned with the overlap between [[artificial intelligence]] and social issues.<ref name=":0" /> Chowdhury used the term to describe looming fears of a so-called “[[Fourth Industrial Revolution]]” following the rise of artificial intelligence.
Moral outsourcing is often applied by technologists to shrink away from their part in building offensive products. In her TED Talk, Chowdhury gives the example of a creator excusing their work by saying they were simply doing their job.<ref name=":0" /> This is a case of moral outsourcing and not taking ownership for the consequences of creation.
When it comes to AI, moral outsourcing allows for creators to decide when the machine is human and when it is a computer - shifting the blame and responsibility of moral plights off of the technologists and onto the technology. Conversations around AI and bias and its impacts require accountability to bring change. It is difficult to address these biased systems if their creators use moral outsourcing to avoid taking any responsibility for the issue.<ref name=":1" />
One example of moral outsourcing is the anger that is directed at machines for “taking jobs away from humans” rather than companies for employing that technology and jeopardizing jobs in the first place.<ref name=":0" />
The term "moral outsourcing" refers to the concept of [[outsourcing]], or enlisting an external operation to complete specific work for another organization. In the case of moral outsourcing, the work of resolving moral dilemmas or making choices according to an ethical code is supposed to be conducted by another entity.<ref name=":2" /> == Real-World Applications == In the medical field, AI is increasingly involved in decision-making processes about which patients to treat, and how to treat them.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Shaikh |first=Sonia Jawaid |date=2020 |title=Artificial Intelligence and Resource Allocation in Health Care: The Process-Outcome Divide in Perspectives on Moral Decision-Making |url=https://ceur-ws.org/Vol-2884/paper_122.pdf |journal=Symposium on AI for Social Good}}</ref> The responsibility of the doctor to make informed decisions about what is best for their patients is outsourced to an algorithm. Sympathy is also noted to be an important part of medical practice; an aspect that artificial intelligence, glaringly, is missing.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Farhud |first1=Dariush D. |last2=Zokaei |first2=Shaghayegh |date=2021-10-27 |title=Ethical Issues of Artificial Intelligence in Medicine and Healthcare |url=https://publish.kne-publishing.com/index.php/ijph/article/view/7600 |journal=Iranian Journal of Public Health |volume=50 |issue=11 |pages=i-v |doi=10.18502/ijph.v50i11.7600 |issn=2251-6093 |pmc=8826344 |pmid=35223619}}</ref> This form of moral outsourcing is a major concern in the medical community.
Another field of technology in which moral outsourcing is frequently brought up is [[Self-driving car|autonomous vehicles]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |date=2016-05-28 |title=How will driverless cars make life-or-death decisions? |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/how-will-driverless-cars-make-life-or-death-decisions |access-date=2023-11-28 |website=PBS NewsHour |language=en-us}}</ref> [[California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo|California Polytechnic State University]] professor Keith Abney proposed an example scenario: "Suppose we have some [troublemaking] teenagers, and they see an autonomous vehicle, they drive right at it. They know the autonomous vehicle will swerve off the road and go off a cliff, but should it?"<ref name=":3" /> The decision of whether to sacrifice the autonomous vehicle (and any passengers inside) or the vehicle coming at it will be written into the algorithms defining the car's behavior. In the case of moral outsourcing, the responsibility of any damage caused by an accident may be attributed to the autonomous vehicle itself, rather than the creators who wrote protocol the vehicle will use to "decide" what to do.<ref name=":0" />
Moral outsourcing is also used to delegate the consequences of [[predictive policing]] algorithms to technology, rather than the creators or the police. There are many ethical concerns with predictive policing due to the fact that it results in the over-policing of low income and minority communities. <ref>{{Cite web |last=VCE |date=2022-02-17 |title=Pitfalls of Predictive Policing: An Ethical Analysis |url=https://vce.usc.edu/volume-5-issue-3/pitfalls-of-predictive-policing-an-ethical-analysis/ |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=Viterbi Conversations in Ethics |language=en-US}}</ref> In the context of moral outsourcing, the positive feedback loop of sending disproportionate police forces into minority communities is attributed to the algorithm and the data being fed into this system--rather than the users and creators of the predictive policing technology.
== Outside of Technology ==
=== Religion === Moral outsourcing is also commonly seen in appeals to [[religion]] to justify [[discrimination]] or harm. In his book ''What It Means to be Moral,'' sociologist [[Phil Zuckerman]] contradicts the popular religious notion that [[morality]] comes from God. Religion is oftentimes cited as a foundation for a moral stance without any tangible relation between the religious beliefs and personal stance.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=McKay |first1=Ryan |last2=Whitehouse |first2=Harvey |date=March 2015 |title=Religion and morality. |journal=Psychological Bulletin |language=en |volume=141 |issue=2 |pages=447–473 |doi=10.1037/a0038455 |issn=1939-1455|doi-access=free |pmid=25528346 |pmc=4345965 }}</ref> In these cases, religious individuals will "outsource" their personal beliefs and opinions by claiming that they are a result of their religious identification. This is seen where religion is cited as a factor for political beliefs,<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Graham |first1=Jesse |last2=Haidt |first2=Jonathan |date=February 2010 |title=Beyond Beliefs: Religions Bind Individuals Into Moral Communities |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1088868309353415 |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Review |language=en |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=140–150 |doi=10.1177/1088868309353415 |pmid=20089848 |s2cid=264630346 |issn=1088-8683|url-access=subscription }}</ref> medical beliefs,<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Pelčić |first1=Gordana |last2=Karačić |first2=Silvana |last3=Mikirtichan |first3=Galina L. |last4=Kubar |first4=Olga I. |last5=Leavitt |first5=Frank J. |last6=Cheng-tek Tai |first6=Michael |last7=Morishita |first7=Naoki |last8=Vuletić |first8=Suzana |last9=Tomašević |first9=Luka |date=October 2016 |title=Religious exception for vaccination or religious excuses for avoiding vaccination |journal=Croatian Medical Journal |volume=57 |issue=5 |pages=516–521 |doi=10.3325/cmj.2016.57.516 |issn=0353-9504 |pmc=5141457 |pmid=27815943}}</ref> and in extreme cases an excuse for violence.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Gonçalves |first1=Juliane Piasseschi de Bernardin |last2=Lucchetti |first2=Giancarlo |last3=Maraldi |first3=Everton de Oliveira |last4=Fernandez |first4=Paulo Eduardo Lahoz |last5=Menezes |first5=Paulo Rossi |last6=Vallada |first6=Homero |date=2023 |title=The role of religiosity and spirituality in interpersonal violence: a systematic review and meta-analysis |url=https://www.bjp.org.br/details/2327/en-US/the-role-of-religiosity-and-spirituality-in-interpersonal-violence--a-systematic-review-and-meta-analysis |journal=Brazilian Journal of Psychiatry |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=162–181 |doi=10.47626/1516-4446-2022-2832 |pmc=10154014 |pmid=36331229}}</ref>
=== Manufacturing === Moral outsourcing can also be seen in the business world in terms of manufacturing goods and avoiding environmental responsibility. Some companies in the United States will move their production process to foreign countries with more relaxed environmental policies to avoid the pollution laws that exist in the US. A study by the [[Harvard Business Review]] found that "in countries with tight environmental regulation, companies have 29% lower domestic emissions on average. On the other hand, such a tightening in regulation results in 43% higher emissions abroad."<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Ben-David |first1=Itzhak (Zahi) |last2=Kleimeier |first2=Stefanie |last3=Viehs |first3=Michael |date=2019-02-04 |title=Research: When Environmental Regulations Are Tighter at Home, Companies Emit More Abroad |work=Harvard Business Review |url=https://hbr.org/2019/02/research-when-environmental-regulations-are-tighter-at-home-companies-emit-more-abroad |access-date=2023-11-30 |issn=0017-8012}}</ref> The consequences of higher pollution rates are then attributed to the loose regulations in these countries, rather than on the companies themselves who purposefully moved into these areas to avoid strict pollution policy.
== [[Rumman Chowdhury]] == Chowdhury has a prominent voice in the discussions about the intersection of ethics and AI. Her ideas have been included in The Atlantic,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Chowdhury |first=Rumman |date=2023-02-17 |title=I Watched Elon Musk Kill Twitter's Culture From the Inside |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2023/02/elon-musk-twitter-ethics-algorithm-biases/673110/ |access-date=2023-10-14 |website=The Atlantic |language=en}}</ref> Forbes,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Chowdhury |first=Rumman |title=Moral Outsourcing: Finding the Humanity in Artificial Intelligence |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rummanchowdhury/2017/10/13/moral-outsourcing-2/ |access-date=2023-10-14 |website=Forbes |language=en}}</ref> MIT Technology Review,<ref>{{Cite web |title=What is an "algorithm"? It depends whom you ask |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/02/26/1020007/what-is-an-algorithm/ |access-date=2023-10-14 |website=MIT Technology Review |language=en}}</ref> and the Harvard Business Review.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-06-16 |title=How to Practice Responsible AI |work=Harvard Business Review |url=https://hbr.org/podcast/2021/06/how-to-practice-responsible-ai |access-date=2023-10-14 |issn=0017-8012}}</ref>

{{Essay-like|date=September 2024}} Systems cause '''representational harm''' when they misrepresent a group of people in a negative manner. Representational harms include perpetuating harmful [[stereotype]]s about or minimizing the existence of a social group, such as a racial, ethnic, gender, or religious group.<ref name=":3">{{Cite thesis |last=Blodgett |first=Su Lin |date=2021-04-06 |title=Sociolinguistically Driven Approaches for Just Natural Language Processing |url=https://scholarworks.umass.edu/dissertations_2/2092 |journal=Doctoral Dissertations |doi=10.7275/20410631}}</ref> [[Machine learning]] algorithms often commit representational harm when they learn patterns from data that have [[algorithmic bias]], and this has been shown to be the case with [[large language model]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Luo |first=Yiwei |last2=Gligorić |first2=Kristina |last3=Jurafsky |first3=Dan |date=2024-05-28 |title=Othering and Low Status Framing of Immigrant Cuisines in US Restaurant Reviews and Large Language Models |url=https://ojs.aaai.org/index.php/ICWSM/article/view/31367 |journal=Proceedings of the International AAAI Conference on Web and Social Media |language=en |volume=18 |pages=985–998 |doi=10.1609/icwsm.v18i1.31367 |issn=2334-0770|arxiv=2307.07645 }}</ref> While preventing representational harm in models is essential to prevent harmful biases, researchers often lack precise definitions of representational harm and conflate it with allocative harm, an unequal distribution of resources among social groups, which is more widely studied and easier to measure.<ref name=":3" /> However, recognition of representational harms is growing and preventing them has become an active research area. Researchers have recently developed methods to effectively quantify representational harm in algorithms, making progress on preventing this harm in the future.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Types == Three prominent types of representational harm include stereotyping, denigration, and misrecognition.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Rusanen |first1=Anna-Mari |last2=Nurminen |first2=Jukka K. |title=Ethics of Ai |url=https://ethics-of-ai.mooc.fi/ |website=ethics-of-ai.mooc.fi}}</ref> These subcategories present many dangers to individuals and groups.
Stereotypes are oversimplified and usually undesirable representations of a specific group of people, usually by race and gender. This often leads to the denial of educational, employment, housing, and other opportunities.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book |last1=Shelby |first1=Renee |last2=Rismani |first2=Shalaleh |last3=Henne |first3=Kathryn |last4=Moon |first4=AJung |last5=Rostamzadeh |first5=Negar |last6=Nicholas |first6=Paul |last7=Yilla-Akbari |first7=N'Mah |last8=Gallegos |first8=Jess |last9=Smart |first9=Andrew |last10=Garcia |first10=Emilio |last11=Virk |first11=Gurleen |chapter=Sociotechnical Harms of Algorithmic Systems: Scoping a Taxonomy for Harm Reduction |date=2023-08-29 |title=Proceedings of the 2023 AAAI/ACM Conference on AI, Ethics, and Society |chapter-url=https://doi.org/10.1145/3600211.3604673 |series=AIES '23 |location=New York, NY, USA |publisher=Association for Computing Machinery |pages=723–741 |doi=10.1145/3600211.3604673 |isbn=979-8-4007-0231-0|s2cid=256697294 }}</ref> For example, the [[model minority]] stereotype of Asian Americans as highly intelligent and good at mathematics can be damaging professionally and academically.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Trytten |first1=Deborah A. |last2=Lowe |first2=Anna Wong |last3=Walden |first3=Susan E. |date=January 2, 2013 |title="Asians are Good at Math. What an Awful Stereotype" The Model Minority Stereotype's Impact on Asian American Engineering Students |journal=Journal of Engineering Education |language=en |volume=101 |issue=3 |pages=439–468 |doi=10.1002/j.2168-9830.2012.tb00057.x |s2cid=144783391 |issn=1069-4730|doi-access=free }}</ref>
Representational harm happens when the representation of details teams improves damaging [[stereotype]]s, developing [[social exclusion]] and [[prejudice]]. This experience is particularly noticeable in the depiction of marginalised groups, containing [[Person of color|people of color]], women, [[LGBTQ|LGBTQ+]] people, and people with handicaps. Media depictions of these groups generally stop working to catch their array and intricacy. Instead, they are typically reduced to one-dimensional caricatures, which ultimately continue social prejudices. These organised depictions contribute to the help of hazardous [[stereotype]]s and the marginalisation of these locations.
Denigration is the action of unfairly criticizing individuals. This frequently happens when the demeaning of social groups occurs.<ref name=":2" /> For example, when searching for "Black-sounding" names versus "white-sounding" ones, some retrieval systems bolster the false perception of criminality by displaying ads for bail-bonding businesses.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sweeney |first=Latanya |date=2013-03-01 |title=Discrimination in Online Ad Delivery: Google ads, black names and white names, racial discrimination, and click advertising |journal=Queue |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=10–29 |doi=10.1145/2460276.2460278 |s2cid=35894627 |issn=1542-7730|doi-access=free |arxiv=1301.6822 }}</ref> A system may shift the representation of a group to be of lower [[social status]], often resulting in a disregard from society.<ref name=":2" />
Research shows that hazardous depictions in the media can have substantial emotional and social impacts on both individuals and areas. [[Lawrence D. Bobo|Lawrence Bobo]] examined the issue of [[Ethnic stereotype]] in film, tv, and marketing. [[African Americans]] are commonly received duties specified by features such as "[[Violence|violent]] tendencies," "[[laziness]]," or being "merely for contentment features." While these representations might appear varied externally, they stay to boost underlying frameworks of white prominence and racial inequality.<ref>'''Bobo, Lawrence D.''' "Race, Sociopolitical Participation, and Black Empowerment." ''American Political Science Review'', vol. 90, no. 3, 1996, pp. 493-508. ''Cambridge University Press'', <nowiki>https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-political-science-review/article/abs/race-sociopolitical-participation-and-black-empowerment/09E117B5F7C747E746EB60A18448A364</nowiki></ref> As a circumstances, Black individuals are frequently represented as law offenders or in secondary roles, which adds to the support of [[Ethnic stereotype]] and [[Institutional racism]].
Misrecognition, or incorrect [[Recognition (sociology)|recognition]], can display in many forms, including, but not limited to, erasing and alienating social groups, and denying people the right to self-identify.<ref name=":2" /> Erasing and alienating social groups involves the unequal visibility of certain social groups; specifically, systematic ineligibility in algorithmic systems perpetuates inequality by contributing to the underrepresentation of social groups.<ref name=":2" /> Not allowing people to self-identify is closely related as people's identities can be 'erased' or 'alienated' in these algorithms. Misrecognition causes more than surface-level harm to individuals: [[Psychological trauma|psychological harm]], [[social isolation]], and [[Emotional security|emotional insecurity]] can emerge from this subcategory of representational harm.<ref name=":2" />
== Quantification == As the dangers of representational harm have become better understood, some researchers have developed methods to measure representational harm in algorithms.
Modeling stereotyping is one way to identify representational harm. Representational stereotyping can be quantified by comparing the predicted outcomes for one social group with the ground-truth outcomes for that group observed in real data.<ref name=":0">{{Cite arXiv |last1=Abbasi |first1=Mohsen |last2=Friedler |first2=Sorelle |last3=Scheidegger |first3=Carlos |last4=Venkatasubramanian |first4=Suresh |date=28 January 2019 |title=Fairness in representation: quantifying stereotyping as representational harm |class=cs.LG |eprint=1901.09565 }}</ref> For example, if individuals from group A achieve an outcome with a probability of 60%, stereotyping would be observed if it predicted individuals to achieve that outcome with a probability greater than 60%.<ref name=":0" /> The group modeled stereotyping in the context of [[Classification in machine learning|classification]], [[Regression analysis|regression]], and [[Cluster analysis|clustering]] problems, and developed a set of rules to quantitatively determine if the model predictions exhibit stereotyping in each of these cases.{{Citation needed|date=December 2023}}
Other attempts to measure representational harms have focused on applications of algorithms in specific domains such as [[image captioning]], the act of an algorithm generating a short description of an image. In a study on image captioning, researchers measured five types of representational harm. To quantify stereotyping, they measured the number of incorrect words included in the model-generated image caption when compared to a [[Gold standard (test)|gold-standard]] caption.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book |last1=Wang |first1=Angelina |last2=Barocas |first2=Solon |last3=Laird |first3=Kristen |last4=Wallach |first4=Hanna |chapter=Measuring Representational Harms in Image Captioning |date=2022-06-20 |title=2022 ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency |chapter-url=https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3531146.3533099 |series=FAccT '22 |location=New York, NY, USA |publisher=Association for Computing Machinery |pages=324–335 |doi=10.1145/3531146.3533099 |isbn=978-1-4503-9352-2|s2cid=249674329 }}</ref> They manually reviewed each of the incorrectly included words, determining whether the incorrect word reflected a stereotype associated with the image or whether it was an unrelated error, which allowed them to have a [[proxy measure]] of the amount of stereotyping occurring in this caption generation.<ref name=":1" /> These researchers also attempted to measure demeaning representational harm. To measure this, they analyzed the frequency with which humans in the image were mentioned in the generated caption. It was hypothesized that if the individuals were not mentioned in the caption, then this was a form of [[dehumanization]].<ref name=":1" />
== Examples == One of the most notorious examples of representational harm was committed by [[Google]] in 2015 when an algorithm in Google Photos classified Black people as gorillas.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2015-07-01 |title=Google apologises for Photos app's racist blunder |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-33347866 |access-date=2023-12-06}}</ref> Developers at Google said that the problem was caused because there were not enough faces of Black people in the training dataset for the algorithm to learn the difference between Black people and gorillas.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last1=Grant |first1=Nico |last2=Hill |date=May 22, 2023 |title=Google's Photo App Still Can't Find Gorillas. And Neither Can Apple's. |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/22/technology/ai-photo-labels-google-apple.html |access-date=December 5, 2023}}</ref> Google issued an apology and fixed the issue by blocking its algorithms from classifying anything as a primate.<ref name=":4" /> In 2023, Google's photos algorithm was still blocked from identifying gorillas in photos.<ref name=":4" />
Another prevalent example of representational harm is the possibility of stereotypes being encoded in [[word embedding]]s, which are trained using a wide range of text. These word embeddings are the representation of a word as an [[Array (data structure)|array of numbers]] in [[vector space]], which allows an individual to calculate the relationships and similarities between words.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Major |first1=Vincent |last2=Surkis |first2=Alisa |last3=Aphinyanaphongs |first3=Yindalon |date=2018 |title=Utility of General and Specific Word Embeddings for Classifying Translational Stages of Research |journal=AMIA ... Annual Symposium Proceedings. AMIA Symposium |volume=2018 |pages=1405–1414 |issn=1942-597X |pmc=6371342 |pmid=30815185}}</ref> However, recent studies have shown that these word embeddings may commonly encode harmful stereotypes, such as the common example that the phrase "[[Programmer|computer programmer]]" is oftentimes more closely related to "man" than it is to "women" in vector space.<ref>{{Cite arXiv |last1=Bolukbasi |first1=Tolga |last2=Chang |first2=Kai-Wei |last3=Zou |first3=James |last4=Saligrama |first4=Venkatesh |last5=Kalai |first5=Adam |date=21 Jul 2016 |title=Man is to Computer Programmer as Woman is to Homemaker? Debiasing Word Embeddings |class=cs.CL |eprint=1607.06520 }}</ref> This could be interpreted as a [[misrepresentation]] of computer programming as a profession that is better performed by men, which would be an example of representational harm.
== Addressing representational harm == Initiatives to minimise representational harm include advertising for even more inclusive and accurate portrayals of marginalised teams in the media. Scholars and protestors recommend that the method to reducing representational injury depends on raising the selection of voices both behind and before the digital video camera. When marginalized groups are provided the chance to represent themselves, they can check traditional stereotypes and present their experiences additional authentically.
Over the last few years, efforts to increase representation of people of color, women, and LGBTQ+ people in conventional media have made some progression. Films such as [[Selma (film)|Selma]], routed by [[Ava DuVernay]], and tv serise like [[Pose (TV series)|Pose]], developed by [[Ryan Murphy (producer)|Ryan Murphy]], have actually been extensively applauded for their nuanced and respectful representations of marginalised communities. These tasks existing complex individualities and stories that move past streamlined stereotypes.
Self-representation is one more crucial method to addressing representational harm. By equipping marginalised locations to create their really own tales, media designers can effectively reduce the perpetuation of hazardous stereotypes. This procedure consists of both the manufacturing of media product by participants of these communities and proactively difficult typical media structures that have actually historically omitted them.

{{Short description|New York City lighted moving news ticker since 1928}} The '''Motograph News Bulletin''', also known as the '''Zipper''', was a 380-feet-long [[Electromechanics|electromechanical]] [[news ticker]] display that wrapped around [[One Times Square]].{{Cite magazine |last=Long |first=Tony |title=Nov. 6, 1928: All the News That's Lit |language=en-US |magazine=Wired |url=https://www.wired.com/2008/11/nov-6-1928-all-the-news-thats-lit/ |access-date=2023-12-08 |issn=1059-1028}} == History == === Development and installation === Frank C. Reilly and Francis EJ Wilde, both engineers at ''Motogram,'' developed the technology used in the display.{{Cite book |last=Cressman |first=Dale |url=https://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3114&context=facpub |title=News in Lights: The Times Square Zipper and Newspaper Signs in an Age of Technological Enthusiasm |publisher=All Faculty Publication |year=2018}} While similar illuminated displays existed at the time, they all had disadvantages. Wilde patented many devices which helped overcome these shortcomings.''Electric Sign'', American patent ref. US1626899A, registered on September 23, 1925 and applied on May 3, 1927; ''Electric-Sign Control'' American patent ref. US1626900A, registered on March 24, 1926 and applied on May 3, 1927 In 1926, Reilly proposed the idea of installing a news ticker bulletin on the Times Tower to the owner of the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' [[Adolph Ochs]] and deputy [[Arthur Hays Sulzberger]]. They all signed a contract July 26, 1928. It took 8 weeks to install the display with work being done 24 hours a day in order to meet the contracted deadline. The ''Times'' wanted to pay a maximum of $50,000 but due to the fact it was unique and custom manufactured along with several difficulties unforeseen during the installation process, ''Motogram'' ended up paying $80,000 for it. This led to increased animosity between the two companies. The first headline displayed was the announcement of [[Herbert Hoover]]'s victory over [[Al Smith]] on November 6, 1928. The display read: ''HOOVER DEFEATS AL SMITH.'' The New York Times wrote and published an article, titled ''HUGE TIMES SIGN WILL FLASH NEWS,'' describing the device. === Subsequent history === The Motograph quickly became an icon of New York City. It appeared in many films of the time. On May 18, 1942, it was extinguished for the first time in history in order to comply with the black-out orders given by the military.At the time, German submariners took advantage of the artificial lighting of large cities on the east coast of the United States to visually detect ships along the coast and torpedo them. On the morning of August 14, 1945 at 07:30 (EST), the following message was displayed on the Motograph: ''***OFFICIAL - TRUMAN ANNOUNCES JAPANESE SURRENDER***.'' James Torpey, the person responsible for composing the headlines and general operation, had spent nearly a day in order to make sure the headline was correct. He came up with the idea of adding 3 stars to the beginning and end of the headline which represented the 3 branches of the American armed forces. Almost 750,000 people crowded around the building to read the headline, the largest audience the Motograph would ever see likely due to the proliferation of television.Lawrence Van Gelder, ''Lights Out for Times Square News Signs?'', article from the ''New York Times'', December 11, 1994 The Motograph operated continuously until 1961, when the ''Times'' moved out of the building. The tower was subsequently purchased by [[Allied Chemical]] in 1963. The display was put back into service in 1965 but would only operate sporadically, with some gaps lasting several years. In 1975, the Motograph was extinguished. ''[[Newsday]]'' rented the display in 1980, putting it back into service once more. However, in December 1994, ''Newsday'' announced the lease would terminate at the end of the month citing profitability with Chiara Coletti commenting "Frankly, there's not that much bang for the buck." === Replacement === The Motograph was eventually replaced by a new display in 1997, utilizing 227,200 amber LEDs. The headlines are currently sourced from ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''. == Technical aspects == === Exterior display === The display wrapped around the 3rd floor of the building. It was made up of 14,800 incandescent bulbs distributed in a rectangular frame {{convert|368|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} long and {{convert|5|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} tall.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/14/insider/platform-agnostic-for-nearly-100-years.html |title=In Times Past: Platform Agnostic for Nearly 100 Years |last=Dunlap |first=David W. |date=14 May 2023 |website=The New York Times |access-date=28 October 2024}} Each of the letters displayed consisted of a matrix 12 bulbs vertically and 7 bulbs horizontally. All of these bulbs were connected by vast amount of wiring to the device which allowed the letters to be displayed.Joe McKendry, ''One Times Square: A Century of Change at the Crossroads of the World'', 2012, David R. Godine editions, ( {{ISBN|978-1-56792-364-3}} ) === Composition of headlines === In order to compose a headline, an operator would place thin metal plates {{convert|19|by|7.6|cm|in|abbr=on}} with the letters making up the headlines in relief onto a frame. The frame would move along a conveyor belt to a field of brushes each connected to individual lightbulbs. This would cause the lightbulbs to flash in a manner making up the individual letters, thus displaying the headline. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Technology]]

{{Short description|Closed-loop geothermal, a new type of geothermal energy system}}
'''Closed-loop geothermal''' systems (also known as “advanced geothermal systems” or “AGS”) are a type of engineered [[geothermal energy]] system containing subsurface working fluid that is heated in a hot rock reservoir without direct contact with rock pores and fractures.:<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Superhot Rock Energy Glossary |url=https://www.catf.us/superhot-rock/glossary/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=Clean Air Task Force |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-05-10 |title=Next-Generation Geothermal Technologies Are Heating Up |url=https://about.bnef.com/blog/next-generation-geothermal-technologies-are-heating-up/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=BloombergNEF |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Matthews |first=Dylan |date=2023-09-13 |title=Is the future of energy ... pouring water on hot rocks in the ground? |url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/23825844/geothermal-enhanced-fervo-demonstration-superhot |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=Vox |language=en}}</ref> Instead, the subsurface working fluid stays inside a closed loop of deeply buried pipes that conduct Earth’s heat. Closed-loop geothermal systems are one of the prominent categories of next-generation geothermal systems in development today.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=Next-Generation Geothermal Power |url=https://liftoff.energy.gov/next-generation-geothermal-power/ |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Pathways to Commercial Liftoff |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=DOE Unveils Roadmap for the Next Generation of Geothermal Power |url=https://www.energy.gov/articles/doe-unveils-roadmap-next-generation-geothermal-power |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Energy.gov |date=18 March 2024 |language=en}}</ref> [[File:Geothermal technology overview.png|thumb|''Geothermal technology overview across conventional (left) and next-generation (right) designs.''<ref name=":1"/>]] Like all geothermal systems, closed-loop geothermal systems provide [[renewable energy]], and primarily operate as baseload resources that produce energy at a constant rate.<ref>{{Cite web |title=5 Things to Know About Geothermal Power |url=https://www.energy.gov/eere/articles/5-things-know-about-geothermal-power |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Energy.gov |language=en}}</ref> Unlike conventional [[geothermal energy]] plants, closed-loop geothermal plants can be placed anywhere in the world, depending only on the depth of the hot rock resource.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Closed-loop geothermal projects are under development in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Japan]], and [[Germany]].
== Technology == [[File:ClosedLoopGeothermal.png|thumb|Illustration of two basic setups for closed-loop geothermal systems, the U-tube (left), and the tube-in-tube (right).<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=New tool models viability of closed-loop geothermal systems |url=https://newsreleases.sandia.gov/geothermal_modeling/ |access-date=2024-04-18 |language=en}}</ref>]] Closed-loop geothermal companies use a wide variety of engineered systems to produce geothermal energy. These systems primarily vary based on the length and geometry of the closed-loop wells placed subsurface, but can also vary in the materials used in well construction and the working fluid used.
Two commons designs of closed-loop geothermal systems are the U-tube and the tube-in-tube:<ref name=":3" />
* '''U-tube closed-loop geothermal:''' In this system, cool water is pumped down one deep vertical pipe, which then extends horizontally for a certain distance at a depth where the rock is hot and then comes up in a different location. The horizontal section may be composed of one or multiple lateral (horizontal) well sections. * '''Tube-in-a-tube closed-loop geothermal:''' In this system, the cool water is pumped down along the outer layer of a pipe to a certain depth, at which point the pipe may extend an additional horizontal distance at that depth. When the hot water hits the end of the pipe it is pushed into the inner pipe, through which the hot water returns to the surface. Also called a coaxial or pipe-in-pipe system.
== Research and development == Several closed-loop geothermal systems have been demonstrated globally. One commercial closed-loop geothermal project is under construction in Geretsried, Germany. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Table: List of closed-loop geothermal projects (non-exhaustive). !Project Name !Country !State/Region !Year Start !Technology Provider(s) !Status !References |- |J-NEC Method New Geothermal Power System |Japan |[[Kyushu|Kyūshū]] & [[Okinawa Prefecture|Okinawa]] |2016 |J-NEC, [[Kyoto University]] |Demonstration |<ref>{{Cite web |last=GeoEnergy |first=Think |date=2016-11-11 |title=Successful demonstration of closed-loop geothermal plant in Kokonoe, Japan {{!}} ThinkGeoEnergy - Geothermal Energy News |url=https://www.thinkgeoenergy.com/successful-demonstration-of-closed-loop-geothermal-plant-in-kokonoe-japan/ |access-date=2024-03-30 |language=en-US}}</ref> |- |Eavor-Lite |Canada |Alberta |2019 |[[Eavor Technologies|Eavor]] |Demonstration |<ref>{{Cite web |title=Eavor-Lite™ - Eavor - Demonstrating a New Energy Solution |url=https://www.eavor.com/eavor-lite/ |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Eavor |language=en}}</ref> |- |Closed-Loop Geothermal Demonstration Project |United States |California |2020 |GreenFire Energy |Demonstration |<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-06-19 |title=GreenFire Energy Inc. Completes the World's First Field-Scale Demonstration of Closed-Loop Geothermal Energy and the Final Report to the California Energy Commission |url=https://www.geothermalcanada.org/news/2020/6/19/greenfire-energy-inc-completes-the-worlds-first-field-scale-demonstration-of-closed-loop-geothermal-energy-and-the-final-report-to-the-california-energy-commission |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Geothermal Canada |language=en-US}}</ref> |- |Advanced Closed Loop Pilot |Japan |Niseko |2023 |[[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]],[[MOECO]] |Demonstration |<ref>{{Cite web |last=GeoEnergy |first=Think |date=2023-06-22 |title=Chevron and MOECO to pilot test closed-loop geothermal in Hokkaido, Japan |url=https://www.thinkgeoenergy.com/chevron-and-moeco-to-pilot-test-closed-loop-geothermal-in-hokkaido-japan/ |access-date=2024-03-30 |language=en-US}}</ref> |- |Eavor-Loop Geretsried |Germany |Bavaria |2024 |[[Eavor Technologies|Eavor]] |Construction |<ref>{{Cite web |title=Eavor-Loop™ Geretsried |url=https://eavor-geretsried.de/en/ |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Eavor-Loop™ Geretsried |language=en-US}}</ref> |}
== Advantages == The advantages of a deep, closed-loop geothermal circuit include<ref>{{Cite web |last=Roberts |first=David |date=2020-10-21 |title=Geothermal energy is poised for a big breakout |url=https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2020/10/21/21515461/renewable-energy-geothermal-egs-ags-supercritical |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=Vox |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=New Opportunities and Applications for Closed-Loop Geothermal Energy Systems {{!}} Geothermal Rising :: Using the Earth to Save the Earth |url=https://geothermal.org/our-impact/blog/new-opportunities-and-applications-closed-loop-geothermal-energy-systems |access-date=2024-03-31 |website=geothermal.org}}</ref>
# No need for a geofluid # No need for the hot rock to be permeable or porous # All the introduced working fluid can be recirculated with zero loss # No [[fracking]] or stimulation is required to establish the engineered geothermal reservoir.
These advantages mean closed-loop geothermal systems can be placed anywhere in the world as a source of [[Carbon-free and nuclear-free energy|carbon-free]], baseload energy, with no impact to natural water resources and significantly reduced risk of [[induced seismicity]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Geothermal Anywhere |url=https://www.nrel.gov/geothermal/anywhere.html |access-date=2024-03-30 |website=www.nrel.gov |language=en}}</ref>
== Related terminology ==
=== Hot dry rock ===
Hot dry rock (HDR) is an abundant source of [[geothermal energy]], but it is typically difficult to access. Hot, dry crystalline [[Basement (geology)|basement]] rocks are found almost everywhere sufficiently far beneath the surface.<ref>{{cite journal |date=November 2022 |title=Superhot Rock Energy: A Vision for Firm, Global Zero-Carbon Energy |url=https://www.catf.us/resource/superhot-rock-energy-a-vision-for-firm-global-zero-carbon-energy/ |journal=Clean Air Task Force}}</ref>[[File:CATF_superhot_rock_energy_project_map.jpg|thumb|Map of current and planned superhot rock energy projects]] Multiple deep hot dry rock wells have been drilled around the world, including the US, Japan, Australia, France, and the UK.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ball |first1=Philip |title=Superhot Rock Project Map |url=https://www.catf.us/shrmap/ |website=Clean Air Task Force}}</ref> Whereas hydrothermal energy production can exploit already present hot fluids, HDR recovers heat from dry rock via the circulation of an artificially introduced working fluid. Ongoing efforts are underway to further develop and test technologies that can produce [[geothermal energy]] from hot dry rock, including [[Enhanced geothermal system|Enhanced Geothermal Systems]] and Closed-Loop Geothermal Systems.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Adler |first1=Ben |date=11 January 2023 |title=Geothermal energy poised for boom, as U.S. looks to follow Iceland's lead |url=https://news.yahoo.com/geothermal-energy-poised-for-boom-as-us-looks-to-follow-icelands-lead-100022399.html |access-date=18 January 2023 |website=Yahoo News}}</ref>
=== Closed-loop geothermal systems vs. ground source heat pumps === Closed-loop geothermal systems are not to be confused with the [[ground source heat pump]]s used for small-scale, largely residential heating and cooling. While both systems use underground closed-loop circuits of working fluid, there are important differences in the depth, temperature, scale, and applications for each system:
* '''Depth:''' Ground source heat pumps are placed at shallow depths, less than 400 feet (122 meters).<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |title=Geothermal Heat Pumps |url=https://www.energy.gov/energysaver/geothermal-heat-pumps |access-date=2024-04-13 |website=Energy.gov |language=en}}</ref> Closed-loop geothermal systems are drilled much deeper, greater than 1640 feet (500 meters), to access the hotter rock found at greater depths (see: [[geothermal gradient]]). * '''Temperature:''' Ground source heat pumps target shallow ground temperatures, which vary seasonally from 45 °F (7 °C) to 75 °F (21 °C).<ref name=":2" /> Closed-loop geothermal systems target much hotter underground temperatures, greater than 212 °F (100 °C), to produce larger volumes of energy. * '''Scale:''' Ground source heat pumps are used for small-scale residential heating and cooling and typically produce less than 1 kilowatt of thermal energy.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Energy |first=Dandelion |date=2020-02-10 |title=Do Geothermal Heat Pumps Raise Your Electric Bill? - Dandelion Energy |url=https://dandelionenergy.com/geothermal-heat-pump-electricity-usage |access-date=2024-04-14 |website=Dandelion Energy {{!}} Energy Efficiency in Home Heating |language=en-US}}</ref> Closed-Loop Geothermal Systems are used for utility-scale commercial and industrial energy production and typically produce greater than 1 megawatt of thermal energy. * '''Application:''' Ground source heat pumps are most often used for small-scale residential and commercial buildings, and are only used for heating and cooling applications.<ref name=":2" /> Closed-loop geothermal systems are most suitable for large-scale commercial and industrial use, and can be used for electricity production, in addition to 'direct use' heating and cooling.
See the [[glossary of geothermal heating and cooling]] page for further clarification.
