{{Short description|Nigerian AI technology company}} {{Promotional|date=April 2025}} Centre for Digitization of Indigenous African Languages, CDIAL is a technology company focused on [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) for the enterprise, specializing in [[language model]]s in low-resourced languages, research, and deployment. The organization was founded in 2021 and is headquartered in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, US]] with offices in [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Indigenius AI |url=https://indigenius.ai/about |access-date=2024-07-08 |website=indigenius.ai}}</ref>
{{Infobox institute | name = CDIAL AI | founder = Yinka Iyinolakan | established = 2021 | mission = Localizing digital access regardless of language, technological expertise, or economic status. | key_people = Yinka Iyinolakan, Shona Olalere, Soji Akinlabi | location = Lagos, Nigeria. Los Angeles, US. | website = https://indigenius.ai/ }}
In 2023, CDIAL launched its technology, Indigenius Mobile, a conversational AI platform for multilingual communication and interaction.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-09-29 |title=CDIAL Unveils AI Technology that Speaks 4 Nigerian Languages - Brand Times |url=https://www.brandtimes.com.ng/cdial-unveils-ai-technology-that-speaks-4-nigerian-languages/ |access-date=2024-07-08 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last= |date=2022-06-11 |title=Digitizing Local Languages for the Fourth Industrial Revolution |url=https://businessday.ng/bd-weekender/article/digitizing-local-languages-for-the-fourth-industrial-revolution/ |access-date=2024-07-08 |website=Businessday NG |language=en-US}}</ref> CDIAL also released its multilingual smart [[Keyboard technology|Keyboard]] designed to enable communication in 180 African languages and allow users to communicate in their native languages.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Firm Launches Multi-lingual Computer Keyboard – THISDAYLIVE |url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2023/05/05/firm-launches-multi-lingual-computer-keyboard/ |access-date=2024-07-09 |website=www.thisdaylive.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Oba |first=John |date=2023-05-08 |title=Company launches keyboard to enhance communication in 180 African languages |url=https://blueprint.ng/company-launches-keyboard-to-enhance-communication-in-180-african-languages/ |access-date=2024-07-09 |website=Blueprint Newspapers Limited |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mH0WPAf8er8 |title=Indigenius: The Multilingual Keyboard That Speaks Your Language |date=2023-05-25 |last=CDIAL AI |access-date=2024-07-10 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
In May 2023, CDIAL unveiled a dictionary that translates modern words into native languages covering new existing words not contained in native dictionaries.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ijaseun |first=David |date=2023-01-21 |title=Firm launches dictionary for modern words in native languages |url=https://businessday.ng/news/article/firm-launches-dictionary-for-modern-words-in-native-languages/ |access-date=2024-07-09 |website=Businessday NG |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 29, 2023 |title=CDIAL unveils dictionary for modern words in native languages |url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2023/01/cdial-unveils-dictionary-for-modern-words-in-native-languages/ |access-date=2024-07-09 |website=Vanguard Newspaper}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o4YYmj3vCwQ |title=Introducing The CDIAL Dictionary |date=2023-02-09 |last=CDIAL AI |access-date=2024-07-10 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
== History == The organization was officially established in 2021 by three [[Nigerians]], Yinka Iyinolakan, Soji Akinlabi, and Shona Olalere setting out on a mission to localize digital access and digitize indigenous languages,<ref>{{Cite web |title=CDIAL Holds Panel Session on DigitiSing Indigenous Languages at 2022 Social Media Week – THISDAYLIVE |url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2022/03/05/cdial-holds-panel-session-on-digitizing-indigenous-languages-at-2022-social-media-week/#google_vignette |access-date=2024-07-30 |website=www.thisdaylive.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=CDIAL aims to bridge the digital divide in Africa {{!}} Jamlab |url=https://jamlab.africa/cdial-aims-to-bridge-the-digital-divide-in-africa/ |access-date=2024-07-30 |language=en-US}}</ref> including building technology that businesses can use to deploy customer support agents, chatbots, search engines, copywriting, translation, summarization, and other AI-driven products.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Indigenius AI |url=https://indigenius.ai/indigenius |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=indigenius.ai}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> CDIAL products include the Indigenius app on [[Play Store]], enterprise [[API]] solutions for translation and speech recognition, and hardware systems supporting African languages<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Aimuengheuwa |first=Joan |date=2023-12-04 |title=A Chat with Yinka Iyinolakan on CDIAL.AI's Innovative Solutions for Multilingual Africa |url=https://techeconomy.ng/a-chat-with-yinka-iyinolakan-on-cdial-ai-innovative-solutions-for-multilingual-africa/ |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=Tech {{!}} Business {{!}} Economy |language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Milestones == In 2023, CDIAL got a $50,000 Prize at [[Pharrell Williams|Pharrell Williams']] Black Ambition third annual demo day [[competition]], in a ceremony held in [[Tribeca, New York]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Pharrell Williams' Black Ambition Awards $3.2 Million Dollars to 36 Entrepreneurs at Third Annual "Demo Day" – Black Ambition Prize |url=https://blackambitionprize.com/announcements/pharrell-williams-black-ambition-awards-3-2-million-dollars-to-36-entrepreneurs-at-third-annual-demo-day/ |website=blackambitionprize.com |date=November 14, 2023 |access-date=2024-07-24 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Eromosele |first=Fortune |date=November 15, 2023 |title=CDIAL.AI's 'Indigenius' wins prestigious black ambition prize |url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2023/11/cdial-ais-indigenius-wins-prestigious-black-ambition-prize/ |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=Vanguard Nigeria}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-13 |title=Diverse Innovators Shine at Pharrell's Black Ambition Prize 2023: Discover the Champions |url=https://hyfin.org/2023/11/13/diverse-innovators-shine-at-pharrells-black-ambition-prize-2023-discover-the-champions/ |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=HYFIN |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2024, CDIAL received the Innovative and Technology Award presented by Nigeria's vice president,[[Kashim Shettima]] on behalf of [[Federal Government of Nigeria|the Federal Government of Nigeria]] as part of its 2024 MSME Day support program,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-01 |title=MSMEs Award: FG splashes millions, cars on 15 companies - Daily Trust |url=https://dailytrust.com/msmes-award-fg-splashes-millions-cars-on-15-companies/ |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=Daily Trust Newspaper |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-02 |title=MSME AWARD: FG gifts millions in cash, new cars to top 15 companies - SMALL BUSINESS INSIGHTS |url=https://smallbusinessinsights.ng/msme-award-fg-gifts-millions-in-cash-new-cars-to-top-15-companies/ |access-date=2024-07-15 |language=en-US}}</ref> and was listed as part of the first cohort of ten innovative startups by Accelerate Africa,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dabafinance - Accelerate Africa selects 10 African startups for pioneer cohort |url=https://dabafinance.com/news/accelerate-africa-selects-10-african-startups-for-pioneer-cohort |access-date=2024-07-10 |website=Dabafinance |language=en}}</ref> an accelerator program striving to be the [[Y Combinator]] of Africa. [[Google]] also selected CDIAL for its Cohort 8 Africa accelerator program for startups.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Akintaro |first=Samson |date=2024-07-30 |title=Google selects five Nigerian startups for cohort 8 of Africa accelerator program |url=https://nairametrics.com/2024/07/30/google-selects-five-nigerian-startups-for-cohort-8-of-africa-accelerator-program/ |access-date=2024-07-30 |website=Nairametrics |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-30 |title=Meet The 8th Cohort Of Google For Startups Accelerator Africa |url=https://techfinancials.co.za/2024/07/30/meet-the-8th-cohort-of-google-for-startups-accelerator-africa/ |access-date=2024-07-30 |website=techfinancials.co.za |language=en-ZA}}</ref>
== References == <references />

{{Short description|UK cyber security law proposal in 2024}}
On July 17th 2024, it was announced at the [[2024 State Opening of Parliament| State Opening of Parliament]] that the [[Labour Party (UK)| Labour]] government will introduce the Cyber Security and Resilience Bill (CS&R).<ref name=CSRB_1>{{cite news| title=Key points in King's Speech at a glance| author=Seddon, P.| url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c51y7pqy1v3o| date=15 July 2024| publisher=[[BBC News]]| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> The proposed legislation is intended to update the existing Network and Information Security Regulations 2018, known as UK NIS.<ref name=CSPM_1>{{cite web| title=King's Speech: new cyber resilience laws planned in the UK| url=https://www.pinsentmasons.com/out-law/news/king-speech-uk-nis2-trailed-cyber-resilience-law-announced| publisher=Pinsent Masons| date=17 July 2024| access-date=5 August 2024}}</ref> CS&R will strengthen the UK's [[Proactive cyber defence| cyber defences]] and [[Cyber resilience| resilience]] to hostile attacks thus ensuring that the infrastructure and critical services relied upon by [[United Kingdom| UK]] companies are protected by addressing [[Vulnerability (computer security)| vulnerabilities]], while ensuring the [[digital economy]] can deliver [[Economic growth| growth]].<ref name=CSRB_7>{{cite web| title=The King's Speech 2024| url=https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/6697f5c10808eaf43b50d18e/The_King_s_Speech_2024_background_briefing_notes.pdf| publisher=UK GOV| page=94| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref>
The legislation will expand the remit of the existing regulations and put regulators on a stronger footing, as well as increasing the reporting requirements placed on businesses to help build a better picture of cyber threats.<ref name=CSRB_2>{{cite news| title=Labour announces host of new tech rules – but does not reveal much-hyped 'AI bill'| author=Griffin, A.| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/tech/labour-kings-speech-ai-bill-new-tech-b2581383.html| publisher=[[The Independent|Independent]]| date=17 July 2024| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> Its aim is to strengthen UK cyber defences, ensuring that the critical [[infrastructure]] and digital services which companies rely on are secure.<ref name=CSRB_3>{{cite web| title=Government announces new Bill to strengthen the UK's cyber security and resilience| author1=Patefield, D.| author2=Broom, J.| author3=Collings, A.| author4=Tsolova, R.| author5=Modha, T.| url=https://www.techuk.org/resource/government-announces-new-bill-to-strengthen-the-uk-s-cyber-security-and-resilience.html| publisher=techUK| date=19 July 2024| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> The Bill will extend and apply UK-wide.<ref name=CSRB_7/>
The new laws are part of the Government's pledge to enhance and strengthen UK [[cyber security]] measures and protect the digital economy.<ref name=CSRB_4>{{cite web| title=Cyber Security and Resilience Bill: what businesses and insurers need to know| url=https://cms-lawnow.com/en/ealerts/2024/07/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-what-businesses-and-insurers-need-to-know| publisher=CMS Legal| date=18 July 2024| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> CS&R will introduce a comprehensive regulatory framework designed to enforce stringent cyber security measures across various sectors. This framework will include mandatory compliance with established cyber security standards and practices to ensure essential cyber safety measures are being implemented. Ultimately, businesses will need to demonstrate their adherence to these standards through regular audits and reporting.<ref name=CSRB_5>{{cite news| title=What businesses need to know about the Cyber Security and Resilience Bill| url=https://business.itn.co.uk/what-businesses-need-to-know-about-the-cyber-security-and-resilience-bill| publisher=[[ITN]]| date=22 July 2024| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref> Also included in the legislation are potential cost recovery mechanisms to provide resources to regulators and provide powers to proactively investigate potential vulnerabilities.<ref name=CSRB_6>{{cite web| title=UK set to debut Cyber Security and Resilience Bill to boost national cyber defenses, secure critical infrastructure| url=https://industrialcyber.co/regulation-standards-and-compliance/uk-set-to-debut-cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-to-boost-national-cyber-defenses-secure-critical-infrastructure| publisher=Industrial Cyber| date=19 July 2024| access-date=30 July 2024}}</ref>
== Key facts ==
The key facts from the King's Speech are:<ref name=CSRB_7/> {{blockquote| '''i''') The current UK NIS cyber security regulations play an essential role in safeguarding the UK’s critical national infrastructure by placing security duties on industry involved in the delivery of essential services.<ref name=NIS_1>{{cite web| title=The Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018| url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2018/506/made| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=10 May 2024| access-date=4 August 2024}}</ref> These regulations cover the five sectors of transport, energy, [[drinking water]], health and digital infrastructure, as well as some digital services including [[online marketplace]]s, online search engines, and cloud computing services. 12 regulators are responsible for implementing the present regulations.
'''ii)''' Hostile cyber actors are increasingly targeting UK critical sectors and supply chains. Recent serious high-profile attacks impacting London hospitals and the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)| Ministry of Defence]], as well as [[ransomware]] attacks on the [[British Library]] and [[Royal Mail]], have highlighted that UK services and institutions are vulnerable to attack.
'''iii)''' The impacts of a cyber attack on these sectors pose severe risks to UK citizens, core services and the economy at large. For example, as a result of the ransomware attack affecting the [[NHS]] in England in June [2024], 3,396 outpatient appointments and 1,255 elective procedures were postponed across [[King's College Hospital]], [[Guy’s Hospital]] and [[St Thomas’ Hospital]], all in South London. It has been estimated that the cost of cybercrime in the UK in 2023 was $320 billion, near £225 billion.<ref name=SCS_1>{{cite web| title=Annual cost of cybercrime in the UK 2017-2028| url=https://www.statista.com/forecasts/1425776/uk-cybercrime-cost-annual| publisher=Ani Petrosyan| date=1 December 2023| access-date=7 August 2024}}</ref>
'''iv)''' The [[National Cyber Security Centre (United Kingdom)| National Cyber Security Centre]] (NCSC) assess that the increased threat from [[Cyberwarfare| hostile states]] and state-sponsored actors continues to escalate. At a recent speech at CyberUK, NCSC [[Chief executive officer| CEO]] Felicity Oswald warned that providers of essential services in the UK cannot afford to ignore these threats.<ref name=CBUK_1>{{cite web| title=CYBERUK 2024: Felicity Oswald keynote speech| url=https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/speech/cyberuk-2024-ncsc-ceo-keynote-speech| publisher=[[National Cyber Security Centre (United Kingdom)|National Cyber Security Centre]]| date=May 2024| access-date=15 August 2024}}</ref>
'''v)''' 2 UK NIS Post-Implementation Reviews found that the original regulations are having a positive impact, but that progress has not been fast enough.<ref name="RNIS_1">{{cite web| title=Review of the Network and Information Systems Regulations| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/review-of-the-network-and-information-systems-regulations| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=29 May 2020| access-date=2 November 2024}}</ref><ref name="SPIR_1">{{cite web| title=Second Post-Implementation Review of the Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/second-post-implementation-review-of-the-network-and-information-systems-regulations-2018/second-post-implementation-review-of-the-network-and-information-systems-regulations-2018| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=27 July 2022| access-date=15 August 2024}}</ref> In 2022 the review found that they "are a vital framework in raising wider UK resilience against network and information systems security threats", but updates are required to keep pace with growing threats. Just over half of the operators of essential services have updated or strengthened existing policies and processes since the inception of the UK NIS Regulations in 2018, which were introduced after [[EU]] NIS Directive 2016/1148.<ref name=CSPM_1/><ref name=EU_NIS1>{{cite web| title=Directive (EU) 2016/1148 of the European Parliament and of the Council| url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eudr/2016/1148/contents| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=6 July 2016| access-date=22 August 2024}}</ref>}}
== Consequences ==
It will introduce compulsory ransomware reporting so that the authorities can better understand the threat and "alert us to potential attacks by expanding the type and nature of incidents that regulated entities must report."<ref name=CSRB_4/><ref name=CSIM_1>{{cite web| title=UK Government Set to Introduce New Cyber Security and Resilience Bill| author=Muncaster, P.| url=https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/government-cyber-security-bill-2024| publisher=Reed Exhibitions| date=18 July 2024| access-date=5 August 2024}}</ref> While this information collection is likely to increase resilience to attacks, the administrative burden for businesses from this reporting might well bring with it additional costs as well as the original cyber incident's expense.<ref name=CSRB_4/>
As modern business practices are interconnected, organisations must ensure that their partners and suppliers also adhere to the standards set by the CS&R.<ref name=CSRB_4/>
In the EU, the original Network and Information Security Directive (NIS Directive 2016/1148) is being updated to Directive 2022/2555, known as EU NIS 2.<ref name=TL_1>{{cite web| title=New Cyber Security & Resilience Bill announced in King's Speech| author=Belcheva, R.| url=https://thelens.slaughterandmay.com/post/102je92/new-cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-announced-in-kings-speech| website=The Lens| date=23 July 2024| access-date=13 August 2024}}</ref><ref name=NIS-2>{{cite web| title=The NIS 2 Directive| url=https://www.nis-2-directive.com| publisher=Cyber Risk| date=2022| access-date=13 August 2024}}</ref> EU NIS 2 introduces wide-reaching changes to the existing EU cyber security laws for network and information systems.<ref name=TL_1/> The CS&R should bring the existing UK NIS regulations 2018 to a framework similar to that of the EU.<ref name=TL_1/><ref name="NRD_1">{{cite web| author=Poireault, K.| title= Navigating Regulation Discrepancies: EU's NIS 2 v UK's Cyber Security and Resilience Bill| url=https://www.infosecurityeurope.com/en-gb/blog/regulation-and-policy/eu-nis2-uk-cyber-resilience-bill-compared.html| publisher=[[RELX]]| date=12 August 2024| access-date=26 September 2024}}</ref>
The Bill as yet has no information on any punishments for non-compliance or what the data regulators' demands from an organisation that has experienced a cyber security incident will be.<ref name=CSRB_8>{{cite web| title=Revamped UK cybersecurity bill couldn't come soon enough, but details are patchy| author=Jones, C.| url=https://www.theregister.com/2024/07/30/uk_csr_bill_analysis| website=[[The Register]]| date=30 July 2024| access-date=4 August 2024}}</ref>
== Reaction ==
Jon Ellison, NCSC Director of National Resilience, said that the proposed bill was "a landmark moment tackling the growing threat to the UK's critical systems".<ref name=NHI_1>{{cite web| title=NCSC highlights importance of Cyber Security Bill| author=Say, M.| url=https://www.ukauthority.com/articles/ncsc-highlights-importance-of-cyber-security-bill| publisher=Informed Communications Ltd| date=25 July 2024| access-date=29 August 2024}}</ref> He continued that it will be "a crucial step towards a more comprehensive regulatory regime, fit for our volatile world".<ref name=NHI_1/>
Former head of the NCSC Ciaran Martin along with other experts welcomed the legislative proposal. On social media, he wrote that the proposed legislation seemed sensible, with mandatory reporting requirements being significant and positive steps.<ref name=UKL_1>{{cite web| title=UK Labour Introduces Cyber Security and Resilience Bill| author=Akshaya, A.| url=https://www.bankinfosecurity.com/uk-labour-introduces-cyber-security-resilience-bill-a-25788| publisher=Information Security Media Group| date=17 July 2024| access-date=16 August 2024}}</ref>
A representative of the CyberUp Campaign Matt Hull said that the organisation is looking forward to the Government updating UK cyber resilience and in particular the [[Computer Misuse Act 1990]]. Any updates to this Act would help cyber professionals protect the U.K., safeguard the digital economy and unlock the potential growth within the cybersecurity industry.<ref name=UKL_1/>
== Cyber security and resilience policy statement ==
In April 2025, the CS&R [[Government policy statement| Policy Statement]] was published, which outlines the confirmed and proposed measures to be included in the bill.<ref name="GPP_1">{{cite press release| title=Cyber security and resilience policy statement| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement#cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-measures| website=Department for Science, Innovation & Technology| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=1 April 2025| access-date=15 April 2025| isbn=978-1-5286-5588-0}}</ref> Quoting: "The digital revolution is transforming our [[Critical infrastructure| Critical National Infrastructure (CNI)]] and our essential public services. It offers an extraordinary opportunity – to make our people and our country better off. However, it may also bring new and dangerous vulnerabilities... In this Policy Statement, I set out legislative proposals for this Bill. I also acknowledge that the cyber landscape moves exponentially – a lot can happen in a short space of time. This statement proposes several additional measures to tackle the threats that we are facing now."<ref name="GPP_1"/>
The legislation aims to strengthen the UK's cyber defenses and secure critical infrastructure and essential digital services, thereby enhancing CNI protection.<ref name="ICPS_1">{{cite web| last1=Ribeiro| first1=Anna| title=UK Cyber Security and Resilience Bill: Policy statement details confirmed and proposed measures for enhanced CNI protection| url=https://industrialcyber.co/regulation-standards-and-compliance/uk-cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement-details-confirmed-and-proposed-measures-for-enhanced-cni-protection| website=Industrial Cyber| date=1 April 2025| access-date=15 April 2025}}</ref> The statement details plans to expand the regulatory framework to cover more entities, empower regulators and improve oversight. This includes enhancing incident reporting, augmenting the [[Information Commissioner’s Office| ICO's]] information-gathering capabilities and improving regulators’ cost recovery mechanisms. The bill also addresses the need for an adaptable regulatory framework to keep pace with the ever-evolving cyber landscape.<ref name="ICPS_1"/>
CS&R seeks to broaden the scope of organizations required to improve their risk assessments, strengthening cybersecurity measures for approximately 1000 organizations. <ref name="IMCR_1">{{cite magazine| last1=Muncaster| first1=Phil| title=Cyber Security and Resilience Bill Will Apply to 1000 UK Firms| url=https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/cyber-security-resilience-bill| website=Infosecurity magazine| publisher=[[RELX| Reed Exhibitions]]| date=1 April 2025| access-date=15 April 2025}}</ref> These measures will increase data protection and network security and are likely to include data center operators and [[Managed services| managed service providers]] . The proposals also include giving regulators more tools to enhance security standards, mandating detailed incident reporting and granting the government powers to update regulatory frameworks as threats and technology evolve.<ref name="IMCR_1"/>
The statement provides a detailed overview of the changes to the Cyber Essentials program, including updates to the software definition, vulnerability fixes and terminology related to remote working.<ref name="TUK_1">{{cite web| title=Cyber Security and Resilience Bill - Policy Statement of Intent| url=https://www.techuk.org/resource/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement-of-intent.html| website=TechUK| date=1 April 2025| access-date=15 April 2025}}</ref> The Cyber Essentials Plus test specification will be updated with new verification pointers, verification of segregation by sub-set and verification of sampling. The statement also outlines the steps organizations will need to take to achieve Cyber Essentials certification in 2025 and onwards. These include changes to IT infrastructure requirements, such as the introduction of [[Passwordless authentication| passwordless authentication]].<ref name="TUK_1"/>
== Schedule == {{Main|Act of Parliament (United Kingdom)}} The Bill will proceed through seven stages of the legislative process which happens in both houses of the UK parliament: first reading, second reading, committee stage, report stage, third reading, opposite house and royal assent. # 17 July 2024 - Bill announced.<ref name=CSRB_1/> #1 April 2025 - Cyber security and resilience policy statement (current).<ref name="CSPS_1">{{cite web| title=Cyber security and resilience policy statement| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill-policy-statement| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=1 April 2025| access-date=2 April 2025}}</ref> # Stage: First reading - The Bill will be introduced to Parliament in 2025.<ref name="CSPS_1"/><ref name="CSGO_1">{{cite web| title=Cyber Security and Resilience Bill| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/cyber-security-and-resilience-bill| publisher=[[Crown copyright| Crown]]| date=30 September 2024| access-date=11 October 2024| quote=The Bill will be introduced to Parliament in 2025}}</ref>

{{Short description|Type of subsea quick connector for offboard services}} A '''hot stab''' is a type of subsea connector specifically designed to be easily inserted and removed by a [[remotely operated underwater vehicle]] (ROV) [[manipulator arm]]. The hot stab is the connector which supplies remote utilities. It is normally inserted into a port after removing the plug stab, which is left in the port when the hot stab is disconnected, to keep the port clean and free of fouling when not in use. The alignment is generally not critical for insertion, and the stab is guided into the port by the port geometry, which tends to be concentric cylinder and cone sections, tapering down from the handle end to the tip, with a series of O-ring seals separating the ports or contacts spaced along the length. The stab may be locked into place or may require the ROV to hold it in place while it is in use.<ref name="IADC" /><ref name="PMT" /><ref name="Secc" /><ref name="tekflow" />
==Purpose== A hot stab provides a temporary pressure-tight connection between an external service and a [[subsea installation]], which can be used for a wide variety of applications.<ref name="Secc" />
Some operations require low to medium flow rates for a short period to operate a mechanism from one position to another. These may be called static applications. Other operations need continuous medium or high flow rates.<ref name="Secc" />
==Applications==
*Hydraulic – Used for hydraulic control fluids to operate valves, connectors, actuators, clamps, pumps and other systems.<ref name="Secc" /> *Chemical injection.<ref name="Secc" /> *Electrical power and communication connections.<ref name="Secc" /> *Multifunction hot stabs combine two or more of these services in one connector unit.<ref name="Secc" /> *Bell umbilical services may use a hot stab type connector for emergency services.<ref name="D-BE 2015" /> *There are types defined by geometry and port specifications.<ref name="Secc" />
==Components==
*The stab plate is a fixed position part on the subsea structure<ref name="Secc" /> *The receptacle is the part on the structure into which the hot stab is inserted. It receives and secures the hot stab and contains the static set of ports or contacts.<ref name="Secc" /> *The stab is the mobile component that is inserted into the receptacle by the ROV or diver. The stab which carries the services is the hot stab (or live stab),<ref name="PMT" /> and the plug stab is an unserviced component of the same basic geometry used to close the receptacle when not in use, to keep out detritus and prevent growth of marine fouling, and to keep water out of hydraulic systems.<ref name="Secc" /><ref name="PMT" /> *The seals prevent leakage to the environment and between ports under high pressures. The seals may be pressure balanced to prevent separation forces.<ref name="Secc" /> *Alignment aids may include a guide nose, funnel, bucket, and latches, to facilitate precise alignment of the stab and receptacle.<ref name="Secc" /> *The stab is connected to hoses and/or cables to supply fluids or electrical power or signals to the appropriate ports or contacts. of the receptacle.<ref name="Secc" /> *The handle allows the ROV or diver to grip, manipulate and move the stab.<ref name="Secc" /> *Non-return valves may be used in the stab or receptacle to prevent loss of fluids to the environment.<ref name="Secc" />
The [[American Petroleum Institute]] (API) has published "API 17H recommended practice for subsea production systems", which provides specifications for standard types of hydraulic hot stabs with flow path bores ranging from {{convert|0.25 to 3.5|in|mm}}.<ref name="PMT" />
==Terminology== *The term "stab" is used for the insertable component (pin), the combination of pin and box (receptacle), and the action of inserting the pin into the receptacle.<ref name="IADC" /> *"Hot stab" may refer to the insertable component with services, or to the technology in general.<ref name="IADC" /><ref name="tekflow" /><ref name="PMT" /> *"Live stab" or "live hot stab"refers to the insertable component with services.<ref name="Secc" /> *"Plug stab", "dummy stab", "blind stab" or "parking stab" is the insertable component without services used for blanking off the receptacle.<ref name="Secc" /><ref name="PMT" /> *The receptacle may also be called the "box".<ref name="IADC" />
==Sizing== A hot stab can be specified by the inside diameter of the receptacle, the bore and number of the ports and the type of handle. API/ISO specifications identify stabs by type, size, and port geometry and are interchangeable if the API/ISO-type, size and port specification match.<ref name="Secc" />
==Operation== Removal of the plug stab (also known as the dummy or parking stab) from the receptacle is followed by insertion of the hot stab into the port. This operation can be done by a diver or a ROV with manipulator arm. The stab is not a self-locking mechanism, and though the internal forces may be balanced, an external force is required to secure the stab in place in the receptacle.<ref name="IADC" />
==Standards==
*ISO 13624-1:2009, Petroleum and natural gas industries – Drilling and production equipment – Part 1:Design and operation of marine drilling riser equipment.<ref name="IADC" />

<nowiki>'''</nowiki>'''MarketSpaces by [https://drop-desk.com DropDesk]'''<nowiki>'''</nowiki> (formerly Onboardly) is a technology platform that connects people by unlocking the potential of underutilized spaces. It operates a two-sided marketplace connecting hosts with users seeking spaces for various activities.
DropDesk facilitates:
<nowiki>*</nowiki> **Productivity:** Connecting creators and businesses with suitable spaces, empowering them to work effectively.
<nowiki>*</nowiki> **Space Utilization:** Enabling hosts to monetize unused spaces by simplifying listing, management, and marketing, including handling bookings and payments.
<nowiki>*</nowiki> **Marketplace Development:** Providing tools for businesses and online directories to launch their own two-sided marketplaces, expanding access to local spaces and services.
== History == Onboardly started as a PR and Marketing Agency in July 2012 by Renée Warren and Heather Carson.<ref name = forbes /><ref name = itbusiness>{{cite web | author = Howard Solomon | publisher = ITBusiness | title = Onboardly launches as 'a startup for startups' | date = 2012-10-07 | url = http://www.itbusiness.ca/news/onboardly-launches-as-a-startup-for-startups/18132 | accessdate = 2014-06-28}}</ref> Before Onboardly, Warren was the CEO and co-founder of another [[digital marketing]] agency, Carson ran her own PR consultancy.<ref name = marketingmagazine>{{cite news | author = Russ Martin | title = It's Okay to have a Fear of Commitment | date = July 2012 | work = Marketing Magazine | volume = 117 | issue = 13 | page = 14A}}</ref> Warren and Carson came together to establish Onboardly in an effort to help small, and medium-sized companies, along with [[startup company|startups]].<ref name = marketingmagazine/><ref>{{cite web | author = Ken Hartos | publisher = Skilled Up | title = Learn How To Do PR in 2014 with Heather Carson of Onboardly | date = | url = http://www.skilledup.com/learn/marketing/learn-pr-2014-heather-carson-onboardly/ | accessdate = 2014-06-28}}</ref>
As of May 2020, Onboardly was rebranded under DropDesk's Platform providing Proptech businesses with scalable Software as a service (SaaS) solutions, top tier [[public relations]], [[content marketing]], [[social media]],<ref>{{cite news |last1=Olivia |first1=Patel |title=Baddie Hub |url=https://baddiehub.money/ |access-date=28 Dec 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Charles |first1=James |title=Web Designer |url=https://www.omerfarooq.me/services/freelance-web-designer-dubai/ |access-date=12 June 2019}}</ref> and [[influencer marketing]] through the initial launch phase, initial customer acquisition phase or during high growth phases.<ref name = ocanada >{{cite web | author = Russ Martin | publisher = O Canada | title = Onboardly launches Canadian marketing firm for startups | date = 2012-10-07 | url = http://o.canada.com/technology/onboardly-launches-canadian-marketing-firm-for-startups | accessdate = 2014-06-28}}</ref> The company is based on [[Long Island]], the United States, and other parts of the world.<ref>{{cite web | author = Mike Melanson | publisher = ReadWrite | title = 3 Picks For The Best Business File-Sharing Services | date = 2014-03-17 | url = http://readwrite.com/2014/03/17/file-sharing-services#awesm=~oHntXWiY9T8MKv | accessdate = 2014-06-28}}</ref>

{{Infobox website | name = ''Android Central'' | logo = Android Central logo.svg | logo_alt = Android Central logo | type = [[Technology journalism]] | founded = September 2008 | location_city = [[New York City]] | country = [[United States]], [[Canada]] | country_of_origin = [[United States]] | founder = Dieter Bohn<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bonggolto |first1=Jay |title=Dieter Bohn leaves The Verge to join Google's platforms and ecosystems team |url=https://www.androidcentral.com/dieter-bohn-leaves-the-verge |access-date=26 February 2025 |date=4 March 2022}}</ref> and Casey Chan | editor = Shruti Shekar<ref>{{cite web |title=Shruti Shekar's Profile |url=https://muckrack.com/shruti-shekar |website=Muck Rack |access-date=26 February 2025}}</ref> | CEO = Kevin Li Ying (as of 31 March 2025)<ref>{{cite web |title=Kevin Li Ying Appointed Chief Executive Officer |url=https://futureplc.com/blog/kevin-li-ying-appointed-future-ceo/ |website=Future |publisher=Future plc |access-date=26 February 2025}}</ref> | MD = Paul Newman<ref name="Contact Future" group="Future plc">{{cite web |title=Contact our team |url=https://futureplc.com/contact/ |website=Future |publisher=Future plc |access-date=26 February 2025 |url-status=live}}</ref> | GM = Jeremy Kaplan<ref name="Contact Future" group="Future plc">{{cite web |title=Contact our team |url=https://futureplc.com/contact/ |website=Future |publisher=Future plc |access-date=26 February 2025 |url-status=live}}</ref> | industry = [[Technology journalism]] | parent = [[Future plc]] | url = https://www.androidcentral.com/ | commercial = Yes | current_status = Active }}
'''''Android Central''''' is a [[technology journalism]] website based in the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom that covers the [[Android (operating system)|Android operating system]]. It publishes news, reviews of products and services, and editorials. ''Android Central'' also covers [[Google]], [[Android TV]] and streaming, [[Wear OS]], [[ChromeOS|Chrome OS]], [[Gemini (chatbot)|Gemini]], and [[Android XR]] and [[Virtual reality|VR]] devices in the [[Meta Quest|MetaQuest]] range. According to its archive, the site publishes between 280 and 450 articles a month, on average,<ref>{{Cite web |title=All content archive {{!}} Android Central |url=https://www.androidcentral.com/archive/ |url-status=live |access-date=26 February 2025 |website=Android Central}}</ref> and it received 4.7 million visitors in January 2025, according to [[Similarweb|SimilarWeb]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=androidcentral.com Website Analysis for January 2025 |url=https://www.similarweb.com/website/androidcentral.com/#overview |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250226162915/https://www.similarweb.com/website/androidcentral.com/#overview |archive-date=26 February 2025 |access-date=26 February 2025 |website=[[Similarweb]]}}</ref>
== History == Smartphone Experts – later called Mobile Nations – launched ''Android Central'' in September 2008 under the guidance of [[Dieter Bohn]], later a founding editor of ''[[The Verge]]''.
The first article published on the site was on 25 September, 2008, by Casey Chan, titled "T-Mobile G1 doesn't have a 3.5mm headphone jack."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Chan |first=Casey |date=25 September 2008 |title=T-Mobile G1 Doesn’t Have 3.5mm Headphone Jack |url=https://www.androidcentral.com/t-mobile-g1-doesnt-have-35mm-headphone-jack |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219000337/http://androidcentral.com/t-mobile-g1-doesnt-have-35mm-headphone-jack/ |archive-date=19 February 2009 |access-date=26 February 2025 |work=Android Central}}</ref>
The site has published numerous exclusives and scoops since its founding, including a first look at the 2013 [[Nexus 7 (2013)|Nexus 7]] tablet and the almost-never-released [[HTC Merge]].
In 2019, ''Android Central''’s parent company, Mobile Nations, was acquired by [[Future plc]]<ref>{{Cite web |date=8 March 2019 |title=Future PLC’s U.S. Subsidiary Acquires Mobile Nations |url=https://golenbock.com/future-plcs-u-s-subsidiary-acquires-mobile-nations/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250226163858/https://golenbock.com/future-plcs-u-s-subsidiary-acquires-mobile-nations/ |archive-date=26 February 2025 |access-date=26 February 2025 |website=Golenbock Eiseman Assor Bell & Peskoe LLP}}</ref> for $60 million.<ref>{{Cite web |date=15 March 2019 |title=Future acquires Mobile Nations |url=https://www.inpublishing.co.uk/articles/future-acquires-mobile-nations-14319 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250112204733/https://inpublishing.co.uk/articles/future-acquires-mobile-nations-14319 |archive-date=12 January 2025 |access-date=26 February 2025 |website=InPublishing}}</ref>
In 2024, the site published a series of exclusives on [[Project Orion (Meta)|Meta’s Project Orion]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sutrich |first=Nicholas |date=25 April 2024 |title=Exclusive: Meta's upcoming glasses are the OMG moment that AR needs |url=https://www.androidcentral.com/gaming/virtual-reality/meta-project-nazare-interview-caitlin-kalinowski |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250219212751/https://www.androidcentral.com/gaming/virtual-reality/meta-project-nazare-interview-caitlin-kalinowski |archive-date=19 February 2025 |access-date=26 February 2025 |work=Android Central}}</ref>
== Editorial leadership and notable staff == Canadian journalist Shruti Shekar took over as editor-in-chief of ''Android Central'' in September 2023, succeeding Jeramy Johnson. Shekar frequently appears on the [[Canadian]] network [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] as a guest expert on technology news.<ref>{{Cite news |date=31 August 2024 |title=Tech needs for back to school and your home |url=https://www.cbc.ca/listen/live-radio/1-78-all-in-a-weekend/clip/16091529-tech-needs-back-school-home |url-status=live |access-date=26 February 2025 |work=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]}}</ref>
Derrek Lee is the managing editor of ''Android Central''; he has been with the site since November 2020. Jerry Hildenbrand is responsible for the "Android and Chill column." Dieter Bohn was managing editor of the site from its launch in 2008 through 2011 when he left to help launch ''[[The Verge]]''. Casey Chan was a co-founder of ''Android Central'' who later joined ''[[Gizmodo]]''.
== Android Central awards == Each January, ''Android Central'' issues its Best Of awards, wrapping up the most noteworthy products, services, and technologies of the previous year.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shekar |first=Shruti |date=3 January 2025 |title=Android Central's Best of 2024 Awards: The best phones, smartwatches, tablets, apps, and more |url=https://www.androidcentral.com/phones/android-centrals-best-of-2024-awards-the-best-phones-smartwatches-tablets-apps-and-more |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250116050505/https://www.androidcentral.com/phones/android-centrals-best-of-2024-awards-the-best-phones-smartwatches-tablets-apps-and-more |archive-date=16 January 2025 |access-date=26 February 2025 |website=Android Central}}</ref> The awards recognize the best Android phones, wearables, smart glasses and games, [[Chromebook|Chromebooks]] and tablets, apps and software, and audio accessories. {{Orphan|date=April 2025}} {{Short description|German automation technology company}} {{lowercase title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2020}} {{Infobox company | name = ifm Group | logo = Logo ifm-group RGB.svg | image = Glückaufhaus - ifm - Essen.jpg | image_caption = ifm Headquarters in [[Essen]] | type = [[Private company|Privately held company]] (''[[Stiftung & Co. KG]]'') | founder = Robert Buck
Gerd Marhofer | foundation = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1967|10|26}}
[[Essen]], [[Germany]][https://www.ifm.com/us/en/us/company/global-presence "ifm - a global company"], ''ifm.com''. Retrieved 18 March 2024. | location = [[Essen]], Germany | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Michael Marhofer ([[CEO]])
Martin Buck (Deputy CEO)
Benno Kathan ([[Chief technology officer|CTO]])
Christoph von Rosenberg ([[Chief Technology Officer|CFO]])
Dirk Kristes ([[Chief operating officer|COO]]) | industry = [[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]] | products = industrial automation, software, sensor systems | revenue = {{Increase}} €1,37 billion (2022)[https://www.unternehmensregister.de/ureg/result.html;jsessionid=EE3E6D321A3B9E42462DA84B376EFF30.web04-1?submitaction=showDocument&id=33100552 "Konzernabschluss zum Geschäftsjahr vom 01.01.2022 bis zum 31.12.2022"], ''bundesanzeiger.de''. Retrieved 31 March 2024. | num_employees = 8,760 (2025){{cite web |author= |date= |title=ifm at a glance|url=https://www.ifm.com/us/en/shared/company/ifm-at-a-glance/about-us|website=ifm.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.ifm.com/|ifm.com}} }} The '''ifm group''' is a [[Germany|German]] automation technology company, specialized in components for industrial companies. Its headquarters are located [[Essen]], Germany. The company is considered the inventor of [[inductive sensor#applications|inductive proximity sensors]].{{cite web |author=Chris McCullough|date=10 February 2022|title=ifm Keeps Ahead with Sensor Technology|url=https://emag.directindustry.com/2022/02/10/ifm-sensor-technology-electronics-iot-cloud-processes/|website=emag.directindustry.com|location= |publisher=Direct Industry EMag|access-date=21 April 2025}} ==History== ifm was founded in 1969 by electrical engineer Robert Buck and salesman Gerd Marhofer{{cite magazine |author=|date=17 April 2023|title=Built to last: Michael Marhofer|url=https://www.theceomagazine.com/executive-interviews/manufacturing/michael-marhofer/|magazine=theceomagazine.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2022}} under the name ''ifm electronic geräte gmbh+co kg''.{{cite web |author= |date= |title=Management - Milestones - Development - Locations|url=https://www.ifm.com/hk/en/shared/company/ifm-at-a-glance/milestones|website=ifm.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=21 April 2025}} Buck and Marhofer had worked together in the development and marketing of non-contact sensors. In the same year, Buck and Marhofer introduced [[inductive sensor|inductive proximity sensors]] under the name ''efector'' to the market. In the early years, Bernd Rüsing also served as managing director but left the company in 1971. In the following years, the company grew and expanded into different countries. While having 16 employees in 1970 and sales of 409,000 euros, the company had 260 employees in 1983 and subsidiaries in six different locations, generating 14,8 million in sales. ifm attracted national attention when an attempt was made to bug the company's stand at ''Interkama'' trade fair in 1972 in a case of industrial espionage.{{cite magazine |author=|date=19 March 1972|title=Idealer Tummelplatz für Industriespione|url=https://www.spiegel.de/politik/idealer-tummelplatz-fuer-industriespione-a-6e1759ae-0002-0001-0000-000042945028?context=issue|trans-title=Ideal playground for industrial spies|magazine=Spiegel Politik|language=German|location= |publisher=[[Der Spiegel]]|access-date=22 April 2025}} The following year, ifm introduced the first electronic speed monitor.{{cite book |last=Hoffmann|first=Gisbert|date= 2006|title=Von der Seide zum Sensor: Tettnanger Industrie. Geschichte und Gegenwart|url= |trans-title=From silk to sensor: Tettnang industry: Past and present|language=German|location= |publisher=Förderkreis Heimatkunde Tettnang|pages=183–194|isbn=978-3-88812-207-1|access-date=}} In 1990, ifm published its company philosophy as hardcover book available for all employees. By now, the book has been translated into 16 languages. ==2000 to 2020== In 2001, ifm underwent its first generational change with Martin Buck and Michael Marhofer, the sons of the founders, taking over the management after spending five years in a probationary period. By that moment, Robert Buck and Gerd Marhofer immediately stepped away. With him still being connected to the company, Robert Buck died in 2016 after having been responsible for over 650 patents during his lifespan.{{cite news |author=|date=16 November 2016|title=Robert Buck ist tot: "ifm war sein Lebenswerk"|url=https://www.schwaebische.de/regional/bodensee/tettnang/robert-buck-ist-tot-ifm-war-sein-lebenswerk-357939|trans-title=Robert Buck is dead: “ifm was his life’s work”|work=schwaebische.de|language=German|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} In 2015, ifm efector opened its North American headquarters in the Atwater Corporate Center, in [[Malvern, Pennsylvania]].{{cite news |last=McCullough|first=Brian|date=8 July 2015|title=New ifm efector building slated to open in Atwater|url=https://www.dailylocal.com/2015/07/08/new-ifm-efector-building-slated-to-open-in-atwater/|work=dailylocal.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}}{{cite news |last=McCullough|first=Brian|date=11 August 2015|title=Ifm efector opens new US headquarters in Chester Country|url=https://www.dailylocal.com/2015/08/11/ifm-efector-opens-new-u-s-headquarters-in-chester-county/|work=dailylocal.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} The following year, [[Barack Obama]] and [[Angela Merkel]] visited the ifm booth at [[Hannover Messe]] fair, where they attracted attention trying on [[Virtual Reality]] goggles.{{cite web |editor-last=Lydon|editor-first=Bill|date=21 June 2016|title=President Obama Immersed in Manufacturing Innovation at Hannover Fair 2016|url=https://www.automation.com/en-us/articles/2016-2/president-obama-immersed-in-manufacturing-innovati|website=automation.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} In 2018, the Lighthouse smart home camera was introduced to the market making it possible to distinguish between adults, children and pets. That same year, ifm started construction of ''The Summit'' in [[Siegen]], which is now home to four ifm subsidiaries.{{cite news |author=|date=7 June 2019|title=The Summit am Start: Wir werden Resultate liefern|url=https://www.siegener-zeitung.de/lokales/siegerland/siegen/the-summit-am-start-wir-werden-resultate-liefern-3ALJF554G4QIJDNTGAXLOOTZXA.html|trans-title=The Summit is starting: We will deliver results|work=siegener-zeitung.de|language=German|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} The following year, ifm celebrated its 50th anniversary by reaching a group turnover of 1 billion euros for the first time. ==Since 2020== In 2022, ifm built a green factory in [[Sibiu]], [[Romania]]. The same year, the company generated 1.3 billion euros in sales. During [[COVID-19 pandemic]], ifm efector became one of the key suppliers of medical consumables and components in the US.{{cite news |author=|date=14 October 2022|title=Top COVID-19 Response Manufacturers and Suppliers in the USA |url=https://www.thomasnet.com/articles/top-suppliers/coronavirus-manufacturers-and-suppliers-covid-19-response/|work=thomasnet.com|location= |publisher= |url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230423090322/https://www.thomasnet.com/articles/top-suppliers/coronavirus-manufacturers-and-suppliers-covid-19-response/|archive-date=23 April 2023|access-date=22 April 2025}} As of 2024, ifm produced over 18.3 million products, including 9 million sensors annually. The company had more than 8.750 employees in more than 80 countries and 70 subsidiaries worldwide. In April 2024 it was reported that ifm signed an agreement with US company [[Microsoft]] to develop solutions based on Microsoft Azure.{{cite news |author=|date=25 April 2024|title=ifm and Microsoft sign agreement|url=https://www.wileyindustrynews.com/en/news/ifm-and-microsoft-sign-agreement|work=wileyindustrynews.com|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} In 2025, it was reported by German newspaper [[Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung]] that ifm is primarily growing in international markets. For economic reasons, the company has not yet implemented its plan to build the new company headquarters on the former [[RWE]] site in Essen.{{cite news |last=Lindgens|first=Janet|date=13 January 2025|title=Große Innenstadt-Brache in Essen - auch Ifm verschiebt Neubau|url=https://www.waz.de/lokales/essen/article408071556/grosse-innenstadt-brache-bleibt-auch-ifm-verschiebt-neubau.html|trans-title=Large inner-city wasteland in Essen - Ifm also postpones new construction|work=waz.de|language=German|location= |publisher= |access-date=22 April 2025}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Companies of Germany]] [[Category:Technology]] [[Category:Essen]]

{{unreferenced|date=May 2025}} {{Infobox website | name = Papiamento Wikipedia | logo = Wikipedia-logo-v2-pap.svg | logo_size = 170px | screenshot = File:Papiamento WIkipedia Screenshot.png | screenshot_size = 200px | caption = Main page of the Papiamento Wikipedia in October 2024 | type = [[Online encyclopedia]] | language = [[Papiamento]] | founded = [[26 March]] [[2006]] | owner = [[Wikimedia Foundation]] | creator = [[Wikipedia]] community | url = {{URL|http://pap.wikipedia.org/}} | commercial = No | registration = Optional | users = 10,000+ | current_status = Active }}
'''Wikipedia in Papiamento''' is the [[Papiamento]] edition of the [[online encyclopedia]] [[Wikipedia]]. The Papiamento Wikipedia project has been official since [[March 26]], [[2006]]. As of July 6, 2020 there were about 1,981 articles on the website and more than 10,000 registered users (of which only 18 can be considered "active users").
== Orthography == There are two [[Orthography|orthographies]] of the Papiamento language that are officially recognized. The [[Aruba|Aruban]] orthography of Papiamento, based on etymological principles, uses the letters ''c'' and ''o'' more often, while the orthography used in [[Curaçao]] and [[Bonaire]] is based on phonological principles and uses the letters ''k'' and ''u'' more often. It also differs in use of accent. Wikipedia in Papiamento allows articles in both orthographies, provided that each article maintains consistency in the orthography it uses.
== Article milestones ==
* 1,000 articles - December 12, 2010 * 1,370 articles - June 12, 2014 * 2,100 articles - April 11, 2021 * 2,500 articles - June 10, 2022 * 3,500 articles - October 25, 2023 * 4,000 articles - June 16, 2024 * 4,500 articles - March 17, 2025 * [[Special:Statistics|current number of articles]] [[Category:Technology]]

{{short description|none}} {{for-multi|historical accounts of the development of science|History of science|historical accounts of the development of technology|History of technology|approaches to the study of history of science and technology|Historiography of science}} The '''history of science and technology''' ('''HST''') is a field of [[history]] that examines the development of the understanding of the natural world (science) and humans' ability to manipulate it ([[technology]]) at different points in time. This academic discipline also examines the cultural, economic, and political context and impacts of scientific practices; it likewise may study the consequences of new technologies on existing scientific fields.
==Academic study of history of science== {{See also|Historiography of science|History of technology|History of mathematics}} History of science is an academic discipline with an international community of specialists. Main professional organizations for this field include the [[History of Science Society]], the [[British Society for the History of Science]], and the European Society for the History of Science.
Much of the study of the history of science has been devoted to answering questions about what science ''is'', how it ''functions'', and whether it exhibits large-scale patterns and trends.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dp1f03arcbYC&q=What+is+science&pg=PR11 |title=What is this thing called science? |publisher=Hackett Pub. |year=1999 |isbn=978-0-87220-452-2}}</ref>
=== History of the academic study of history of science === {{Globalize|date=June 2022|section}}[[Historiography of science|Histories of science]] were originally written by practicing and retired scientists,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reingold |first1=Nathan |year=1986 |title=History of Science Today, 1. Uniformity as Hidden Diversity: History of Science in the United States, 1980-1960 |journal=British Journal for the History of Science |volume=19 |issue=3 |pages=243–262 |doi=10.1017/S0007087400023268|s2cid=145350145 }}</ref> starting primarily with [[William Whewell|William Whewell's]] ''History of the Inductive Sciences'' (1837), as a way to communicate the virtues of science to the public.<ref>{{Citation |last=Snyder |first=Laura J. |title=William Whewell |date=2023 |work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |editor-last=Zalta |editor-first=Edward N. |url=https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/whewell/ |access-date=2025-03-09 |edition=Winter 2023 |publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University |editor2-last=Nodelman |editor2-first=Uri}}</ref>
[[Auguste Comte]] proposed that there should be a specific discipline to deal with the history of science.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bourdeau |first1=Michel |title=Auguste Comte |url=https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/comte/ |website=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University |access-date=15 October 2023 |date=2023}}</ref>
The development of the distinct [[Academia|academic]] discipline of the history of science and technology did not occur until the early 20th century.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}} Historians have suggested that this was bound to the changing role of science during the same time period.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}}
After [[World War I]], extensive resources were put into teaching and researching the discipline, with the hopes that it would help the public better understand both Science and Technology as they came to play an exceedingly prominent role in the world.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}}
In the decades since the end of [[World War II]], history of science became an academic discipline, with [[graduate school]]s, [[research institute]]s, public and private patronage, [[peer-review]]ed [[Academic journal|journals]], and professional societies.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}}
==== Formation of academic departments ==== {{Globalize|date=June 2022|section}}In the [[United States]], a more formal study of the history of science as an independent discipline was initiated by [[George Sarton]]'s publications, ''Introduction to the History of Science'' (1927) and the journal [[Isis (journal)|''Isis'']] (founded in 1912).{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}} Sarton exemplified the early 20th-century view of the history of science as the history of great men and great ideas.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}} He shared with many of his contemporaries a [[Whig history#In the history of science|Whiggish]] belief in history as a record of the advances and delays in the march of progress.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}}
The study of the history of science continued to be a small effort until the rise of [[Big Science]] after World War II.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Science Before the War |url=https://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-science-before-the-war |access-date=2025-03-13 |website=The New Atlantis |language=en-US}}</ref> With the work of [[I. Bernard Cohen]] at [[Harvard University]], the history of science began to become an established subdiscipline of history in the United States.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dauben |first1=Joseph W. |last2=Gleason |first2=ML |last3=Smith |first3=GE |name-list-style=vanc |year=2009 |title=Seven Decades of History of Science |journal=Isis |volume=100 |issue=1 |pages=4–35 |doi=10.1086/597575 |pmid=19554868 |s2cid=31401544}}</ref>
In the United States, the influential bureaucrat [[Vannevar Bush]], and the president of Harvard, [[James Bryant Conant|James Conant]], both encouraged the study of the history of science as a way of improving general knowledge about how science worked, and why it was essential to maintain a large scientific workforce.{{Citation needed|date=June 2022}}
== Universities with history of science and technology programs ==
=== Argentina === * [[Instituto Tecnológico de Buenos Aires|Buenos Aires Institute of Technology]], Argentina, has been offering courses on History of the Technology and the Science. ** [[National Technological University]], Argentina, has a complete history program on its offered careers.
=== Australia === * [[The University of Sydney]] offers both undergraduate and postgraduate programmes in the History and Philosophy of Science, run by the Unit for the History and Philosophy of Science, within the Science Faculty. Undergraduate coursework can be completed as part of either a Bachelor of Science or a Bachelor of Arts Degree. Undergraduate study can be furthered by completing an additional Honours year. For postgraduate study, the Unit offers both coursework and research-based degrees. The two course-work based postgraduate degrees are the Graduate Certificate in Science (HPS) and the Graduate Diploma in Science (HPS). The two research based postgraduate degrees are a Master of Science (MSc) and Doctor of Philosophy (PhD).<ref>{{cite web | author = The University of Sydney | title = History and Philosophy of Science | url = http://www.usyd.edu.au/hps | access-date = December 3, 2009 }}</ref>
=== Belgium === * [[University of Liège]], has a Department called Centre d'histoire des Sciences et Techniques.<ref>{{cite web | author = Université de Liège | title = CHST | url = http://chst.european-is.net/ | access-date = January 3, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100205103256/http://chst.european-is.net/ | archive-date = February 5, 2010 | url-status = dead }}</ref>
=== Canada === * [[Carleton University]] Ottawa offer courses in Ancient Science and Technology in its Technology, Society and Environment program. * [[University of Toronto]] has a program in History and Philosophy of Science and Technology.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Toronto | title = History and Philosophy of Science and Technology | url = http://www.chass.utoronto.ca/ihpst/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> * [[Huron University College]] offers a course in the History of Science which follows the development and philosophy of science from 10,000 BCE to the modern day.<ref>url = https://huronatwestern.ca/sites/default/files/Interdisc%20outlines/HISTSCI%202200E%20updated%20Winter%202020%20-%20Doyle.pdf |</ref> * [[University of King's College]] in Halifax, Nova Scotia has a History of Science and Technology Program.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of King's College | title = History of Science & Technology | date = 8 September 2016 | url = http://ukings.ca/area-of-study/history-of-science-and-technology | access-date = November 14, 2016 }}</ref>
=== France === * [[Nantes University]] has a dedicated Department called Centre François Viète.<ref>{{Cite web|last=TEISSIER|first=Pierre|title=Accueil – Centre François Viète d'épistémologie et d'histoire des sciences et des techniques|url=https://cfv.univ-nantes.fr/|access-date=2021-12-17|website=Centre François Viète|language=fr-FR}}</ref> * [[Paris 7 - Denis Diderot University|Paris Diderot University]] (Paris 7) has a Department of History and Philosophy of Science. * A CNRS research center in History and Philosophy of Science [http://www.sphere.univ-paris-diderot.fr/spip.php?rubrique48 SPHERE], affiliated with Paris Diderot University, has a dedicated [http://www.rehseis.cnrs.fr/spip.php?article958 history of technology] section. * [[University of Paris 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne|Pantheon-Sorbonne University]] (Paris 1) has a dedicated [https://web.archive.org/web/20090416200543/http://www-ihpst.univ-paris1.fr/ Institute of History and Philosophy of Science and Technics]. * The [[École Normale Supérieure]] de Paris has a history of science department.
=== Germany === {{Main|Science and technology in Germany}} * [[Technische Universität Berlin]], has a program in the History of Science and Technology.<ref>{{cite web|author=Technische Universität Berlin |title=Philosophy, Theory of Science, and History of Science and Technology |url=http://www.tu-berlin.de/fak1/philosophie/ |access-date=July 30, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719212353/http://www.tu-berlin.de/fak1/philosophie/ |archive-date=July 19, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref> * The {{langx|de|[[Deutsches Museum]]|translation=German Museum|label=none}} of Masterpieces of Science and Technology in [[Munich]] is one of the largest science and technology museums in the world in terms of exhibition space, with about 28,000 exhibited objects from 50 fields of science and technology.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/europe/germany/bavaria/munich/attraction-detail.html?vid=1154654612189|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503095546/https://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/europe/germany/bavaria/munich/26457/deutsches-museum/attraction-detail.html|archive-date=3 May 2012|title=The New York Times Travel Guide |date=10 August 2008 |quote=This is the largest technological museum of its kind in the world. |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=21 May 2024}}</ref><ref>[https://www.deutsches-museum.de/en Website ''Deutsches Museum'']</ref>
=== Greece === * The [[University of Athens]] has a Department of Philosophy and History of Science
=== India === History of science and technology is a well-developed field in India. At least three generations of scholars can be identified. The first generation includes D.D.Kosambi, Dharmpal, Debiprasad Chattopadhyay and Rahman. The second generation mainly consists of [[Ashis Nandy]], [[Deepak Kumar (historian)|Deepak Kumar]], [[Dhruv Raina]], [[S. Irfan Habib]], [[Shiv Visvanathan]], [[Gyan Prakash]], Stan Lourdswamy, V.V. Krishna, [[Itty Abraham]], Richard Grove, Kavita Philip, Mira Nanda and Rob Anderson. There is an emergent third generation that includes scholars like Abha Sur and Jahnavi Phalkey.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rao |first=Mohit M |date=November 6, 2021 |title="'Access to science is what every society needs': Jahnavi Phalkey" |work=The Hindu |url=https://www.thehindu.com/society/access-to-science-is-what-every-society-needs-jahnavi-phalkey/article37337395.ece |url-status=live |access-date=November 21, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121073601/https://www.thehindu.com/society/access-to-science-is-what-every-society-needs-jahnavi-phalkey/article37337395.ece |archive-date=November 21, 2023}}</ref>
'''''Departments and Programmes'''''
The [[National Institute of Science, Technology and Development Studies]] had a research group active in the 1990s which consolidated social history of science as a field of research in India. Currently there are several institutes and university departments offering HST programmes. *Jawaharlal Nehru University has an Mphil-PhD program that offer specialisation in Social History of Science. It is at the History of Science and Education group of the Zakir Husain Centre for Educational Studies (ZHCES) in the School of Social Sciences. Renowned Indian science historians Deepak Kumar and Dhruv Raina teach here. Also, *Centre for Studies in Science Policy has an Mphil-PhD program that offers specialization in Science, Technology, and Society along with various allied subdisciplines. *Central University of Gujarat has an MPhil-PhD programme in Studies in Science, Technology & Innovation Policy at the Centre for Studies in Science, Technology & Innovation Policy (CSSTIP), where Social History of Science and Technology in India is a major emphasis for research and teaching. * [[Banaras Hindu University]] has programs: one in History of Science and Technology at the Faculty of Science and one in Historical and Comparative Studies of the Sciences and the Humanities at the Faculty of Humanities. * [[Andhra University]] has now set History of Science and Technology as a compulsory subject for all the First year B-Tech students.
=== Israel === *[[Tel Aviv University]]. The Cohn Institute for the History and Philosophy of Science and Ideas is a research and graduate teaching institute within the framework of the School of History of [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref>{{cite web | author = Tel Aviv University | title = History and Philosophy of Science | url = http://www.tau.ac.il/~cohn/ | access-date = December 4, 2009 }}</ref> *[[Bar Ilan University|Bar-Ilan University]] has a graduate program in Science, Technology, and Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sts-biu.org/|title=The Graduate Program in Science, Technology and Society at Bar-Ilan University|website=STS @ BIU}}</ref>
=== Japan === *[[Kyoto University]] has a program in the Philosophy and History of Science.<ref>{{cite web | author = Kyoto University | title = Philosophy and History of Science | url = http://www.bun.kyoto-u.ac.jp/phisci/indexe.html |date= November 20, 2010 |access-date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> *[[Tokyo Institute of Technology]] has a program in the History, Philosophy, and Social Studies of Science and Technology.<ref name="Department of History and Philosophy of Science">{{cite web | author = Tokyo Institute of Technology |title=Department of History and Philosophy of Science |url=http://hps.c.u-tokyo.ac.jp/index_en.php |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019134927/http://hps.c.u-tokyo.ac.jp/index_en.php |archive-date=2009-10-19 |access-date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> *[[The University of Tokyo]] has a program in the History and Philosophy of Science.<ref name="Department of History and Philosophy of Science"/>
=== Netherlands === * [[Utrecht University]], has two co-operating programs: one in History and Philosophy of Science at the Faculty of Natural Sciences and one in Historical and Comparative Studies of the Sciences and the Humanities at the Faculty of Humanities.<ref>{{cite web|author=Utrecht University |title=History and Philosophy of Science |url=http://www1.phys.uu.nl/masters/histphilmaster/ |access-date=July 30, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614024909/http://www1.phys.uu.nl/masters/histphilmaster/ |archive-date=June 14, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Utrecht University |title=Historical and Comparative Studies of the Sciences and Humanities |url=http://www2.let.uu.nl/Solis/homelet/master/hiscompstudies/ |access-date=July 30, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614005154/http://www2.let.uu.nl/Solis/homelet/master/hiscompstudies/ |archive-date=June 14, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
=== Poland ===
* [[Institute for the History of Science of the Polish Academy of Sciences]] offers PhD programmes and [[Habilitation|habilitation degrees]] in the fields of History of Science, Technology and Ideas.
=== Russia ===
=== Spain === *[[University of the Basque Country]], offers a master's degree and PhD programme in History and Philosophy of Science and runs since 1952 ''THEORIA. International Journal for Theory, History and Foundations of Science''.<ref>{{cite web| author = University of the Basque Country| title = Máster Universitario en Filosofía, Ciencia y Valores| url = http://www.masterfilosofiacienciayvalores.ehu.es/p106-2000/es/pls/entrada/plew0050.htm_next?p_cod_idioma=CAS&p_en_portal=S&p_anyo_acad=act&p_cod_master=106&p_menu=1| language = es| access-date = August 31, 2011| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130613073416/http://www.masterfilosofiacienciayvalores.ehu.es/p106-2000/es/pls/entrada/plew0050.htm_next?p_cod_idioma=CAS&p_en_portal=S&p_anyo_acad=act&p_cod_master=106&p_menu=1| archive-date = June 13, 2013| url-status = dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = University of the Basque Country | title = THEORIA. International Journal for Theory, History and Foundations of Science | url = http://www.ehu.es/ojs/index.php/THEORIA/index | access-date = August 20, 2011 }}</ref> The university also sponsors the [[Basque Museum of the History of Medicine and Science]], the only open museum of History of Science of [[Spain]], that in the past offered also PhD courses. * [[Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona]], offers a master's degree and PhD programme in HST together with the [[Universitat de Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite web | author = Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona | title = Centre d'Història de la Ciència | url = http://www.uab.cat/cehic/ | access-date = April 10, 2008 }}</ref> * [[Universitat de València]], offers a master's degree and PhD programme in HST together with the [[Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas]].<ref>{{cite web | author = Universitat Valencia | title = Instituto de Historia de la Medicina y de la Ciencia Lopez Piñero | url = http://www.ihmc.uv-csic.es/ | access-date = April 10, 2010 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100409065820/http://www.ihmc.uv-csic.es/ | archive-date = April 9, 2010 }}</ref>
=== Sweden === * [[Linköping University|Linköpings universitet]], has a Science, Technology, and Society program which includes HST.<ref>{{cite web | author = Linköping University | title = ''Tema Teknik och social förändring'' | url = http://www.tema.liu.se/tema-t/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref>
=== Switzerland === * [[University of Bern]], has an undergraduate and a graduate program in the History and Philosophy of Science.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Bern | title = History and Philosophy of Science | url = http://www.philoscience.unibe.ch | access-date = December 21, 2006 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090212215554/http://philoscience.unibe.ch/ | archive-date = February 12, 2009 }}</ref>
'''<big>Ukraine</big>'''
* State University of Infrastructure and Technologies, has a Department of Philosophy and History of Science and technology.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The State University of Infrastructure and Technologies of Ukraine has a Department of Philosophy and History of Science and technology|url=http://duit.edu.ua/kizt/uzt/fint/}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === * [[University of Bristol]] has a masters and PhD program in the Philosophy and History of Science.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Bristol | title = Department of Philosophy | url = http://www.bris.ac.uk/philosophy/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> * [[University of Cambridge]] has an undergraduate course and a large masters and PhD program in the History and Philosophy of Science (including the History of Medicine).<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Cambridge | title = History and Philosophy of Science | url = http://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> * [[University of Durham]] has several undergraduate History of Science modules in the Philosophy department, as well as Masters and PhD programs in the discipline.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Durham | title = Department of Philosophy | url = http://www.dur.ac.uk/philosophy/undergrad/courses/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> * [[University of Kent]] has a Centre for the History of the Sciences, which offers Masters programmes and undergraduate modules.<ref name="Kent">{{cite web|title=History of the Sciences – School of History – University of Kent|url=https://www.kent.ac.uk/history/centres/sciences/index.html|website=www.kent.ac.uk|access-date=7 August 2016}}</ref> * [[University College London]]'s [[Department of Science and Technology Studies]] offers undergraduate programme in History and Philosophy of Science, including two BSc single honour degrees (UCAS V550 and UCAS L391), plus both major and minor streams in history, philosophy and social studies of science in UCL's Natural Sciences programme. The department also offers MSc degrees in History and Philosophy of Science and in the study of contemporary Science, Technology, and Society. An MPhil/PhD research degree is offered, too.<ref>{{cite web | author = University College London | title = Science and Technology Studies | url = http://www.ucl.ac.uk/sts | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> UCL also contains a Centre for the History of Medicine.<ref>{{cite web | author = University College London | title = The Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine | url = http://www.ucl.ac.uk/histmed/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 }}</ref> This operates a small teaching programme in History of Medicine. * [[University of Leeds]] has both undergraduate and graduate programmes in History and Philosophy of Science in the Department of Philosophy.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Leeds | title = History & Philosophy of Science | url = http://www.philosophy.leeds.ac.uk/ | access-date = July 30, 2006 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060804001519/http://www.philosophy.leeds.ac.uk/ | archive-date = August 4, 2006 }}</ref> *[[University of Manchester]] offers undergraduate modules and postgraduate study in History of Science, Technology and Medicine and is sponsored by the Wellcome Trust.<ref>{{cite web | author = University of Manchester | title = History of Science, Technology and Medicine | url = http://www.chstm.manchester.ac.uk/ | access-date = December 12, 2007 }}</ref> *[[University of Oxford]] has a one-year graduate course in 'History of Science: Instruments, Museums, Science, Technology' associated with the [[Museum of the History of Science]].<ref>{{cite web|author=University of Oxford |title=History of Science: Instruments, Museums, Science, Technology |url=http://www.mhs.ox.ac.uk/course/ |access-date=July 30, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719083457/http://www.mhs.ox.ac.uk/course/ |archive-date=July 19, 2006 |url-status=dead }}</ref> * The [[London Centre for the History of Science, Medicine, and Technology]] – this Centre closed in 2013. It was formed in 1987 and ran a taught MSc programme, jointly taught by [[University College London]]'s [[Department of Science and Technology Studies]] and [[Imperial College London]]. The Masters programme transferred to UCL.<ref>{{cite web | author = London Centre for the History of Science, Medicine and Technology | title = History of Science, Medicine and Technology | url = http://www.londoncentre-hstm.ac.uk}}</ref>
=== United States === Academic study of the history of science as an independent discipline was launched by [[George Sarton]] at Harvard with his book ''Introduction to the History of Science'' (1927) and the [[Isis (journal)|''Isis'' journal]] (founded in 1912). Sarton exemplified the early 20th century view of the history of science as the history of great men and great ideas. He shared with many of his contemporaries a Whiggish belief in history as a record of the advances and delays in the march of progress. The History of Science was not a recognized subfield of American history in this period, and most of the work was carried out by interested Scientists and Physicians rather than professional Historians.<ref>Nathan Reingold, "History of Science Today, 1. Uniformity as Hidden Diversity: History of Science in the United States, 1920–1940," ''British Journal for the History of Science'' 1986 19(3): 243–262</ref> With the work of [[I. Bernard Cohen]] at Harvard, the history of Science became an established subdiscipline of history after 1945.<ref>{{cite journal | last1= Dauben | first1= JW | last2= Gleason | first2= ML | last3= Smith | first3= GE | title= Seven decades of history of science: I. Bernard Cohen (1914–2003), second editor of Isis | journal= Isis; an International Review Devoted to the History of Science and Its Cultural Influences | volume= 100 | issue= 1 | pages= 4–35 | year= 2009 | pmid = 19554868 | doi = 10.1086/597575 | s2cid= 31401544 }}</ref>
